(26) the substantial cuts to ATSIC and to indigenous‐related Commonwealth programs represent a massive setback to the process of reconciliation in Australia;
(27) the savage cuts to the ABC, of $209 million over four years, are in complete breach of the Coalition's solemn election promise to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC;
(28) the Budget has failed to honour the promise to maintain levels of arts funding and spend an additional $60 million over three years; and

(29) the Government's plan to substantially increase Commonwealth court and tribunal fees, coupled with deep cuts to legal aid, will result in a severe curtailment of access to justice by many Australians".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak to the government's Appropriation Bill (No. 1). The appropriations set the scene for a better future for Australia. As the Treasurer (Mr Costello) mentioned in his budget speech, the focus is on savings—savings for investment, sustainable growth and real jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The first observation I would like to make is that this is a budget that has been welcomed by middle Australia. They know that this budget turns around the failures of the past and sets this country on track for the future. They know that we cannot live forever beyond our means on the bankcard with ever growing debt. Mainstream Australia understands that hard decisions have to be made and, more importantly, they expect a responsible government to do just that.

The coalition went to the election promising a better deal for families, for small businesses, for real jobs, for older Australians. As well as that, we promised improvements to our health care system and to fix this country's financial system. All of these things have been achieved in this budget. We have, indeed, delivered just that.

I take this opportunity to congratulate the Treasurer on the budget, a budget that is strong but fair. This government has fulfilled its major promises that we took to the Australian electorate in March this year. The Australian people will not forget that it was the previous Labor government, those members opposite, who took great pains to hide the true state of the nation's financial situation from the Australian people. The Labor government hid the fact that the budget outcome for the past year was a deficit of over $10 billion. Such financial dishonesty should never be inflicted on the Australian public again. Therefore, I applaud the Treasurer for initiating the charter of budget honesty that will require a government to make the Australian people aware of the real state of the Treasury's books before they cast their vote.

The financial burden left by 13 years of Labor mismanagement is shared fairly by asking high income earners as well as business to make a contribution. This huge debt problem created by the previous Labor government could not be ignored by this new government, so we have taken the responsibility of fixing that problem, and the Australian people are backing us all the way. Let me refer to an opinion poll published in the Bulletin magazine of 3 September 1996, conducted after the budget was handed down and when Australians had had a chance to digest its contents. Seventy‐seven per cent of respondents view the budget as average or better. Even 60 per cent of Labor's voters agree. This detailed Morgan poll shows the high level of trust the Australian people have in this government.

We have honoured our major election commitments while achieving a major turnaround in the nation's finances. Our central election commitment was to Australia's families. One of our highest priorities as a government is to relieve the financial pressures on low and middle income families with children.

In January this year, while I was campaigning in the seat that I now represent, I produced a report called Canning chasm, which looked at the incomes of families in the electorate of Canning. The report was drawn from Australian Bureau of Statistics data outlining the inequality between families on different incomes in the south‐eastern suburbs of Perth. According to the ABS data, 14.5 per cent of families living in Canning were surviving on incomes of $16,000 or less. Meanwhile, 11 per cent were living on incomes of over $60,000 per annum. This showed the electorate of Canning to be an area that had a great disparity between families who were well‐off and those battlers who struggled daily to make ends meet.

The people I represent in Canning have told me time and time again, as I meet with them around the electorate, that they are very pleased with this budget. And these people represent middle Australia, the battlers to whom we promised a better deal in the election campaign.

The people of Canning also understand that our family tax initiative will really benefit them. This initiative will assist almost two million Australian families and recognises the financial sacrifices made by those families with young children where one parent stays at home. This will provide a great deal of additional assistance for families in my electorate of Canning, as I am sure it will also do to many other families in many other members' electorates.

The family tax initiative, along with other budget initiatives such as the health insurance tax rebate, funding for marriage and relationship education and parenting education programs will all go a long way to helping these families.

In addition to that, there will also be an increase of $5 million a year for emergency relief funding to welfare agencies who help those families who are most in need. This will alleviate the pressure that the majority of Australian families have been feeling over recent years. Australians know our central election commitment was to look after families and we, I believe, have truly met that commitment.

This is also a budget that acknowledges the needs of women and issues such as child care and balancing work and family. Of course these concerns are not unique to women and there are many men who also juggle these commitments today. But women now represent 43 per cent of the paid work force and many women spend different periods of time in and out of the labour market mainly due to family concerns. Through this government's initiatives on family tax measures, freeing up the industrial relations system, making superannuation easier and breaking new ground in marriage and family support, women will benefit greatly.

The coalition also campaigned to give Australians real jobs. This budget takes responsibility for getting employment on track again by helping small business to get back on its feet. Small business is the backbone of the Australian economy, and it is small business that employs the majority of Australians. I note with interest the report and an editorial in the Australian Financial Review on 16 September 1996 reporting that Australia has lost the equivalent of $12 billion in export earnings, forgone partly because of our decline in competitiveness. The Financial Review states:

The previous Labor Government must take the blame for much of this problem. In its final years it has failed to drive forward with those micro‐economic reforms that could have made Australian businesses more flexible and competitive in export markets.
The Financial Review goes on to ask how the business sector can reach its full potential when, and I quote:
It is hobbled by a regulatory environment that impedes our international competitiveness.

The newspaper also notes that the Howard government has already taken initiatives in this area and indeed we have. Our workplace reform legislation and our package of measures to help business will go a long way to strengthen this sector.

The government has already met its commitment to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor to 6 per cent. This means that small business is no longer assessed for provisional tax on income in excess of what it has earned. The capital gains tax rollover relief that was announced in the budget will allow small business to rollover their business assets without capital gains tax disincentive.
This government's industrial relation reforms currently before the parliament will rectify the job‐destroying unfair dismissal laws.

I recently sent a small business survey to all small and large or medium sized businesses in my electorate of Canning, and there are approximately 3,000 of them. I asked them, `If you could fix any problem to help your business or create jobs what would it be?' The most common answer that I got was to fix the unfair dismissal laws brought in by the previous Labor government. Many other business owners also mentioned the fact that they would like to take on apprentices if it was made more feasible for them to do so. Therefore, one aspect that I am particularly pleased with is the apprenticeship scheme announced in this year's budget. The allocation of almost $260 million in incentive payments and wage subsidies will provide real jobs and a real future for young Australians. This government will deliver real jobs—not revolving door training programs which have left people, particularly our youth, despondent about their future and their worth.

Under Labor, the number of apprenticeships dropped to its lowest level in 30 years. In government they favoured countless training programs with fancy names and not much else. They did not work and, unfortunately, many of the people who went through these schemes did not end up working either.

As I mentioned before, the coalition made it clear during the election campaign that one of its central priorities was to tackle Australia's high level of youth unemployment. I believe that the apprenticeship system has always been a tried and true method of getting young Australians into real jobs and I am pleased to see a return to this system.

BREAK.PARA: The budget is about creating real jobs. We are not going to con the unemployed as Labor did. Their training schemes were, in the main, unsuccessful. Sadly, too many people ended up back where they started: unemployed and without a job. It was a cruel and callous hoax. This was a disgusting and totally irresponsible and immoral scam by the previous Labor government, the so‐called champion of the unemployed. This government is not going to use the unemployed as pawns in some gigantic chess game. We in the Howard coalition government have genuine compassion for the unemployed, and we are determined to provide a far better future for them. Let me quote an article published in the Economist on April 6, 1996. Listen very carefully, on the other side. The article says:

In a growing body of research, economists have compared groups of unemployed people who enter government training schemes with similar groups who do not. In almost every case, these studies have found that the schemes have failed to improve either the earnings or the employment prospects of their clients. After surveying the results of various broadly based training programs for unemployed adults, the training‐friendly OECD was forced to conclude in 1994 that there is `remarkably meagre support for the hypothesis that such programs are effective.'

By easing the burden on small business, by introducing the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship scheme, by introducing employment placement enterprises, and by opening these enterprises up to the private sector, we will be creating real jobs for the unemployed.
For the first time in 13 years, the unemployed have real hope that they will be able to get a job. The article in the Economist again says:
Of five Australian training programs studied during 1989‐92, only one could report—
only one, mind you—
that at least half of its participants were either working or studying three months after completion.

Who was in power in 1989‐92? The members opposite: that is who was in power—the members opposite, who grew increasingly out of touch with reality and who had no real plan to fix the problem they had helped create.

Our jobs pathway guarantee program will take school students and give them active work experience and the opportunity to take on apprenticeships or traineeships while still at school, to adequately prepare themselves to adapt to working life. Germany leads the world with this type of scheme, called the `dual‐education system'. Many German 16‐year‐olds sign an apprenticeship contract with local firms to work part‐time in training positions. The rest of the time, they go to a vocational school.

These apprenticeships are not necessarily only for traditional trades or skilled jobs: they also include white‐collar and professional occupations. It is a company apprenticeship scheme that is tied to the educational system. When the apprentice/pupils finish, most get jobs either with their employer or, at the very least, in the field in which they had trained. This scheme works, just as the jobs pathway guarantee program will work, by allowing the education system and industry to work hand in hand to quickly respond to industry needs.

This government is committed to the youth of Australia. It is going to be a very difficult task to raise the standard of literacy and numeracy skills, which has been very much in decline in recent years in Australia. There is presently a new Western Australian designed program that is being piloted at East Maddington Primary School and at other schools in my electorate of Canning. Called `Reading for sure', the program was developed by Perth clinical psychologist Dr Julia Solomon, in an attempt to reduce anxiety in children who were afraid to read for fear of making mistakes in pronunciation.

Dr Solomon's research showed that it was necessary to produce a reading method which could capitalise on the consistent findings that children learnt to read by breaking up the sounds in words. The `Reading for sure' program has already been used in a number of Scottish schools, where it was used to train severely dyslexic students to read. Within 18 months of starting the `Reading for sure' program, most of these students, who had reading skills five years below average for their ages, had caught up to the same reading levels as their peers.

I mention this only because, if we raise a generation of people who have only the most basic reading and writing skills or who cannot even count without a calculator, and if we continue to have a generation like this, industry will not be able to advance. According to the same 6 April article in the Economist that I quoted from earlier, a report released in January this year by Industry in Education, a British employers group, said that what they really needed was not more skills training but people who could actually address an envelope. I have spoken to Dr Kemp, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, about the `Reading for sure' program, and I will continue to lobby for funding for this and other numeracy and literacy skills programs after the budget, so that we can give our youth—and adults, for that matter—the most basic skills of being able to read, write and do arithmetic, so as to assist them to get jobs that will lead to a better future for themselves and for Australia.

I want to point again to the responses I received to the survey I recently sent out to small businesses. They strongly indicate their support for the measures put forth by this government and they particularly agree with our commitment to scrap Labor's unfair dismissal laws, so as to give small business a chance to employ people and to thrive again.

As I drive along the Albany Highway in my electorate of Canning and look at the new developments taking place there, I can see that business confidence has grown with the election of the Howard coalition government. Some very large businesses are expanding, promising higher employment and a much healthier local economy. New shopping complexes and factories are being built, whilst others are being enlarged. This confidence augurs well for the future. I have already stated that small business is Australia's largest employer. We need small businesses in our suburbs and our towns, not only to provide local amenities and facilities but also to provide opportunities and work for families.

My remarks during this appropriation debate have been mainly concerned with the need for small business to succeed, the need for reducing our country's huge bankcard debt created by the previous Labor government and the need for a stable economy. Indeed, we cannot halve our social problems in this country if we cannot solve our fiscal problems. This budget goes a long way to solving our nation's economic ills. I look forward to Australia reaping the social benefits once our economy is back in shape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The budget we are debating today in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) provides further evidence that the coalition government's policies and philosophy stem not from the homes, the workplaces, the communities or the lives of ordinary Australians but rather that they find their genesis amongst the pages of the driest of economic rationalist textbooks and theories. I have no doubt that is primarily from where the previous speaker, the member for Canning (Mrs Johnston), received her economic education.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time I have available today, I would like to highlight some of the ways that this budget impacts on the people of my electorate. Having driven along the Albany Highway this year and noted the similarities between the south‐eastern suburbs of Perth in the electorate of Canning and those of my south‐eastern Melbourne electorate, in particular in the area of Cranbourne, I have no doubt that the two electorates would feel the impact of this budget in very similar ways. Cranbourne is the third fastest‐growing area in Australia and, like the electorate of Canning, could very much be described as typical of middle Australia. The government would no doubt have us believe that Cranbourne and like suburbs around the country were the beneficiaries of this budget, that it was aimed fairly and squarely at them and that they will, in the government's words, no doubt be better off because of it.

It is time that we had a fairly critical look at the glib rhetoric that emanates from the mouths of members of the government, especially in their submissions on this appropriation bill, and to that end I intend to turn to some informed Isaacs local commentary, to see what prospects the budget holds for the people of Cranbourne and, I am sure—by extrapolation—for the people of Canning living on streets that border the Albany Highway.

The Cranbourne District Commander of the Salvation Army, Mr Derek Linsell—who, I might add, was a willing host to the then opposition leader, John Howard, on 5 October last year in a detailed tour of the Salvation Army's jobskills facilities in Cranbourne—recently summed up rather succinctly the fear and despair that this budget places on the lives of ordinary Australians, the kind that the government claims to represent. In the 3 September edition of the Cranbourne Sun newspaper, Mr Linsell attacked both the Victorian and federal governments for putting the budget bottom line ahead of the needs of the poor. In that edition of the Cranbourne Sun Mr Linsell said:

Ultimately this strategy will come back and bite us on the rear end. We're all going to have to get used to 10 per cent of Australians being in an underclass, which will mean more crime, more vandalism and more poverty.
So much, I might add, for the fulfilment of the government's promises to assist the families of middle Australia, as claimed by the honourable member for Canning. Mr Linsell went on to say:
My concern is that we just don't seem to care for people. History shows us that this is not only bad economic policy, it is also bad social policy.

This is the same man who happily led John Howard by the arm around the Salvation Army facilities in Cranbourne late last year. He went on to describe how the situation in Cranbourne, in middle Australia, is deteriorating. He said:
Six or seven people are coming to us every week for emergency housing. That demand has come from nowhere in the past couple of months and some homeless people are living in squats.
Cranbourne is all about people achieving the great Australian dream of having a family and owning a house. Many people come here expecting to get on the housing ladder and find they can't.
Mr Linsell went on to warn that Cranbourne was facing a welfare crisis which could push many recipients into a permanent underclass.

I have no doubt that we can all see worrying signs. We realise that we will always have poor people, to greater or lesser degrees. But the beauty of Australia over the last decade or more has been that we have put a safety net in place. The danger—and this view is shared by Mr Linsell—is that this safety net will simply disappear. I have no doubt that his fears are particularly well‐founded.

This budget will do nothing for those in our community who are struggling to raise their families, run their businesses and achieve their goals in life. The family tax packages offer little because of the cuts that are being brought to bear, whether they be in the fields of education or health. In fact, one of the great urban myths that is developing in this country is that the so‐called easing of unfair dismissal laws will be the great panacea for small businesses which have been the beneficiaries of a low inflation and low interest rate economic regime for several years.
As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) so precisely put it in his address‐in‐reply to the budget:
The message of this budget is don't be sick; don't be old; don't expect to go to university; if you're unemployed, too bad; and if you're young and unemployed, forget it.

I think we should look at some of the impacts of this budget in more detail. I have made some brief mention of cuts to the health portfolio in this budget which targets private hospitals, pensioners and the disadvantaged through a massive reduction in public hospital funding, higher charges for prescriptions and reduced access to dental services. So much for this budget fulfilling the promises, hopes and dreams of middle Australia, as claimed by the member for Canning.

The budget papers indicate that a further $320 million has been cut from grants to the states over the next four years. In addition to the sum of $600 million pro rata health reduction announced at the previous conference, this will dramatically increase hospital waiting lists for those who depend on public hospitals. Pensioners will have to pay an extra $100 million a year for drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The cost of each script will increase to $3.20 without any compensating increase in the pension.

In perhaps one of the more pertinent issues, which has been the subject of complaints to my office in recent weeks, the betrayal of the least well off in our society is compounded by the abolition of the Commonwealth dental program.

The news that the federal budget will end funding of the highly successful Commonwealth dental health program can only be described as callous and miserable. The Commonwealth dental health program was introduced by the previous Labor government in 1994 to assist the states to reduce severe inequality in dental health care in the Australian community.

Under the program, dental health services were available to the holders of pensioner concessions, pensioner health benefits, health care and Commonwealth seniors cards. Some 4,736 health card holders were treated in the electorate of Isaacs alone last year, with nearly 200,000 people across my state of Victoria receiving some form of dental treatment.

The providers of the dental care under this program in the electorate of Isaacs include the Berwickwide Community Health Service which provides both general and emergency dental care to residents of Cranbourne, Berwick and Packenham. It treated 1,389 patients from the town of Cranbourne alone last year, as well as the 528 patients it treated in‐house. The service also referred 861 cases to private dentists.

Similarly, the Frankston Community Health Centre located in the seat of Dunkley provides general and emergency dental care to residents in the Mornington Peninsula and is likely to lose around a half a million dollars due to the budget cuts. It either treated or arranged treatment with private dentists for nearly 6,000 patients from surrounding areas last year. The centre has two dental surgeries and refers any work over its capacity to the approximately 35 locally operating private dentists.

The Chelsea Community Health Centre similarly provides general and emergency dental care to residents in the cities of Kingston and Bayside and treated 2,934 patients last year—a 470 per cent increase over the number of patients it treated before federal funding was introduced. As well as those patients it treats in‐house, the centre also refers between 70 to 100 cases a month to local private dentists.
The Treasurer (Mr Costello), in his budget speech, justified the abolition of this much loved dental health program by saying:
As waiting times for public dental health services have now been reduced, funding for the Commonwealth dental health program will cease.

It looks like the funding abolition will see the waiting lists of these centres blow out, far from being reduced in the future, from around 12 months currently to five years or longer, even for basic dental treatment, blowing the Treasurer's illogical and short‐sighted premise well and truly out of the water.

Patients from Isaacs in need of emergency dental work will be forced to travel into the dental hospital in the city or be forced to pay private dentists to have teeth extracted as the cheapest option available.

The abolition of this program will no doubt be a tragedy as it enabled the less fortunate members of our community who previously received only the most basic of dental care or who missed out all together to receive the dental health care that they both need and deserve.

As the Leader of the Opposition said, it is hard to think of a more callous budget decision in the last decade or one that more clearly breaks the Prime Minister's commitment not to hurt the most vulnerable in our community. Again, so much for this budget fulfilling the promises of Australian middle-class families as submitted by the member for Canning in her speech in this place not a few moments ago.

The security and quality of life of older Australians have also been made much less certain by this year's budget. The decision to force those in need of nursing home care to find the money to pay an up‐front entry fee is an attack on people at a very vulnerable and a very fragile stage of their lives. As we all know, this entry fee will be something like $26,000 but could be as high as $88,000.

On top of the entry fee, nursing home residents who are not full pensioners will be charged nursing home fees of up to $34 per day, or some $12,000 per year. This fee is charged as soon as a person's income goes $1 above the pension free area. The many older Australians—there are many of them who live in Isaacs—who receive care at home via the home and community care program will be faced with much higher user fees for the first time as a result of this budget.

When I returned on the Friday of budget week to my electorate of Isaacs, one of the first functions that I attended on that day was the Longbeach schools district mid-project achievement celebration at the Mordialloc Primary School in the heart of Isaacs. The celebration might have been referred to better as a commemoration rather than a celebration because there was something bitterly ironic in the fact that such a function should take place only days after the federal budget spelt the end for the very program that was being celebrated.

The function celebrated work carried out on 22 schools within the Longbeach schools district under the federal governments new work opportunities program—one of the programs claimed by the member for Canning to have fancy names and not much else. The work included the construction of rotundas, pergolas, amphitheatres, brick and concrete paving, outdoor furniture, garden beds and general building maintenance at schools within the Longbeach district. To date, approximately 50 per cent of those works have been completed.

According to Mr David Turnbull, the project coordinator, participants of this project employed adults who were willing to take the first step on the road to employment. The skill and pride that they have demonstrated in the work they have completed is reflected in the high standard that has been achieved. I can attest to that high standard, having seen many examples of it in and around schools across the electorate.

But the government has decided to shut down over the next 15 months every significant locally run job program, such as new work opportunities, which have helped local people gain the skills, expertise and, most importantly, the self‐esteem and confidence required to take that all‐important first step back into the workplace.

Other labour market programs to be abolished include jobskills, skillshare and jobclubs. Again, these are initiatives which have more than just fancy names. These are initiatives which make the less than confident in our society understand that they can go out there and get work if, through these programs, they are job ready.

But the coalition government has gone back on its promise not to cut labour market programs which help unemployed people find these real jobs. These commonsense programs, such as new work opportunities, have been real success stories, getting people off the dole and providing them with skills and training, which make them attractive to employers.

The 2 September edition of the Frankston Standard newspaper provides us with yet another example of irony. The Liberal member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) is reported as praising the Mornington Peninsula jobsnet campaign for what he called its `meteoric rise' in the number of traineeship places available in the Frankston and Mornington areas. The honourable member rightly pointed out the importance of traineeships and the success of this particular program, which is a joint effort between local business, media and DEETYA, in getting more than half of the trainees into ongoing real jobs.
The irony was provided some two pages later in the same edition of that newspaper in an article entitled `Jobs scheme future doubt'. The first paragraph of that article states:
The Peninsula's successful and much praised job creation campaign, Jobsnet, has been cut adrift by the Federal Government.

Cut adrift—despite its worth being recognised by the member for Dunkley and despite receiving glowing praise from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, when she visited us in relation to the same scheme only last month.

On a budget of $72,000 last financial year, jobsnet created 1,076 extra jobs in that 12 months, with over 280 young people now in permanent work as a result of this program. The Westernport Area Consultative Committee generously donated $15,000 to the program to see it through the coming years—more accurately, to see it through to the end of this year—but its long‐term prospects are in jeopardy. Given the Howard government's own predictions of little or no reduction in the unemployment rate in the foreseeable future, without effective labour programs such as skillshare, jobsnet and new work opportunities, the unemployed face a very bleak future indeed.

I could go on at some length to talk about cuts to legal aid. The pensioner legal aid centre has been the victim of significant cuts to the legal aid budget and no doubt will be devastated by cuts to its budget starting in financial year 1997‐98 of over $33 million—more than 20 per cent of what the Commonwealth spends on legal aid funding. Again, this will impact most savagely on the needy in our society, quite contrary to the submissions by members opposite during this appropriation bill debate.

When I was first elected to parliament I made a pledge to the constituents in Isaacs. That pledge was that I would hold this government accountable to meet the high standards set by previous governments and demanded by the people of Australia in ensuring that the principles of equity, of tolerance and of community which underpin our society are the parameters which guide and control our law makers and those whom we charge to enact those laws.

Along with my colleagues from the Labor Party who have spoken out against many of the provisions of this budget, I believe we have clearly demonstrated that it falls well short of the standards set by previous governments and that—far from being guided by the principles of equity, tolerance and community—the ideology behind this budget is that of the bottom line, an ideology which recognises the cost of everything but the value of nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise today to speak in support of the budget measures announced by this government in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97. This is the first budget of the 38th parliament, and one which takes the first step in turning around the creeping sense of inevitability that was beginning to pervade Australia prior to the 2 March election. No longer must we resign ourselves to a declining standard of aged care, a shrinking small business sector, apathy about the macro‐economic environment and finding real jobs for Australia's long‐term and young unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a bold budget. Not prepared to put off the tough decisions and be content to tighten spending, this government has reaffirmed its commitment to economic responsibility and to providing Australians with real answers to the dilemmas caused by unemployment, public sector debt and a feeling of isolation within the mainstream in Australia towards the decision makers of this country.

This is a firm but fair budget. It is also somewhat of an anticlimax for members on the other side of the House in light of the ridiculous claims that they made before the budget. Unfortunately, the scaremongering and exaggeration about the effects of the budget have continued, as has been so evident by the standard of debate from some of those on the opposite of the House. As the Adelaide Advertiser commented, rarely have Australians been presented with a happier anticlimax. It went on to say that there were actual advantages for families with children and for some couples.

Can we forget the scaremongering of 12 per cent cuts to universities, the reduction of the aged care pension and jobsearch allowances and the number of other untruths spread throughout Australia about the unknown content of the budget? As one newspaper announced, this budget is about priorities and pragmatism.

It makes a priority of those vast sections of the Australian community forgotten and neglected by Labor and also makes a priority of the reduction in debt and deficit with fairness, with this government asking all sections of the Australian community to contribute. It is pragmatic because it does not avoid the challenge of reducing public sector debt, and it is pragmatic in the sense that it highlights the need for long‐term strategies to deal with Australia's chronic unemployment problems.

The coalition has delivered, in the context of the economic mess left by Labor, a sound budget. This government, as has been made abundantly clear in this budget, is about fairness and sharing the burden to undo Labor's economic legacy. The `spend, spend, spend' mentality of Labor has allowed it, like some sugar daddy, to buy its way into Australian political folklore. It irresponsibly increased public spending to feed the ravenous hunger of special interest groups and has pursued a policy of trophy economics, of grand schemes and Keating's so‐called `big picture'.

But I put it to members in this Main Committee that the Commonwealth's ability to continue to provide quality services depends upon a reassessment of the level of public expenditure. To do otherwise would prove to be a far greater threat to the provision of quality services than this budget has been made out to be by the Labor Party.

Under Labor, Australia's economic sovereignty was placed in a perilous position, with our net foreign liabilities, as a proportion of GDP, the third worst in the industrialised world, ranking Australia 45th out of 49 countries in terms of external debt to exports. The uncontrolled spending spree has come to a very necessary end. The deficit, however, will remain an ever present reality. The government will have to work within the economic confines it has created. In true form, the Labor government, instead of contributing to repairing the economic mess that they created, accuses this government of ideologically driven cuts.

If propriety is an ideology, if responsibility to the taxpayer of Australia is an ideology, and if fiscal restraint in light of this economic debt is an ideology, then I and my coalition colleagues stand guilty. I would argue, however, that far from ideology, this is a budget driven by common sense and pragmatism. A `spend, spend, spend' mentality cannot go on forever unabated and without direction or proper financing.

This budget also returns the political momentum of this country back to those who Labor has for so long forgotten and neglected, as is so apparent from the attrition inflicted upon Labor on 2 March. Among their numbers were small businesses everywhere. Labor went into the 1996 election with nothing to offer small business. It is no understatement to say that the coalition has done more for small business in the last six months than Labor did in 13 years.

The reduction of the tax uplift factor, changes to capital gains tax arrangements which will amount to a $150 million tax cut, the provision of information, consultation and support mechanisms, a reduction in red tape and better relations with the tax office and, most importantly, the scrapping of Labor's unfair dismissal laws are among the broad vision this government has for restoring some faith in a crucial sector of the Australian economy. As Max Walsh commented, the bottom line is that the budget is good for business and good for Australia.

Contrary to the lies circulated during the election and again in the lead‐up to budget night, the coalition will continue to index pensions at current rates. What a scandal for the ALP to circulate any information to the contrary to the 14,800 persons on the age pension in my electorate of Adelaide. The government has also eased the burden on self‐funded retirees, providing them with the same tax rebate as pensioners. Couples will now have a tax‐free joint income threshold of $19,850.

In regard to health policy, the government has made up to $250 available to couples and at least $450 available to families to put towards private health insurance. This is a significant step towards undoing the outrageous negligence of private health in this country, which has seen levels of persons covered by private health insurance drop to just 34 per cent. The only way the health crisis can be averted in Australia is by coordinating the recovery of both public and private health sectors. You cannot do that with only one in three people in private health insurance, and Labor never had the answers.

BREAK.PARA: High income earners will face an increased Medicare levy surcharge. That is right and proper. Again, this is a measure aimed at equity and at sharing the responsibilities of Labor's terrible legacy. In addition, there are important improvements to public health. Areas that have received particular attention are the national childhood immunisation program, the national diabetes action plan, maternal and child health, injury prevention, and life education centres.

Improvements in rural health include the setting up of a department of rural health in rural areas, with links to university medical schools; the Institution of John Flynn scholarships for medical students to give them greater exposure to country medical practice; and the provision of financial assistance to help improve locum arrangements.

This government did not create the unemployment disaster in Australia, but we will take the long‐term responsibility and put into place measures that will reduce unemployment. Only a long‐term strategy will do justice to the nature and enormity of the unemployment problem in Australia, and the best and most genuine way of creating more employees is to create more employers.

I have already spoken of the many benefits to the small business sector, but I would like to add that initiatives like the $207 million apprenticeship scheme and the ongoing reduction of interest rates will improve the macro‐economic climate for employers, thus making them more confident about expansion and the increasing of staff numbers. Complemented by the government's intended reforms in the workplace, this is the only way that a long‐term recovery in employment figures can come about.

These measures reveal the mind‐set of the government which is aimed at real solutions, even if the benefits will not be seen overnight. This is in direct contrast with those who are now in opposition who were intent on the bandaid measures and short‐term irresponsible strategies which were so convincingly rejected by the Australian public at the last election.

For all those people on newstart, for the 3,485 people on jobsearch and for the 178 people on the youth training allowance in Adelaide, this is the first good news they have received for some time. Again, putting some balance back into job training, this government has allocated $3.7 million in the next four years to rebuild the decimated apprenticeship and traineeship system.

The budget does not pretend that the problems of long‐term and youth unemployment will be solved overnight, but it does provide real hope to our jobless and the end of the cruel and endless training merry‐go‐round that was the norm under Labor. These budget measures are about real job creation.

The allocation of $20 million over two years to the Australian Taxation Office will boost investigation of the tax avoidance schemes of the super‐rich. This is simply another fair and equitable measure intended to ensure that all sections of the community contribute to restoring financial security for Australia's future.

Much has also been made of the announcements of changes to the higher education portfolio. But let me take this opportunity to remind members that the coalition changes mean that students do not have to pay up‐front fees and will not be denied entry because of an inability to pay. They will be required to pay HECS only when they can best afford it as they recoup the financial and career rewards that the study they have undertaken brings to them.

The message sent out by the opposition parties in regard to full fee‐paying places has been particularly disappointing. Full fee places mean extra places at university over and above those that are funded by the Commonwealth. Overseas students have had the opportunity to buy places at Australian universities for years. Under access and equity principles, surely it is only fair that these opportunities be extended to Australian students.

The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, has stated that the government is firmly committed to maintaining the level of benefits to eligible families which Austudy provides. At the same time, we want to send a strong message to the whole community that well‐off families with extensive assets and on high incomes will not be eligible to receive financial assistance via Austudy.

Again, an element of fairness has been added to the measures already in place. Not only has the coalition government set about undoing the mess left by Labor, but it has gone as far as possible to ensure that this situation never repeats itself. The charter of budget honesty will ensure that this shameful chapter in Australia's economic history is brought to an end.

Let me remind members that last year the previous Labor government spent $10 billion of taxpayers' money to repay interest on government debt, both here and overseas. The public sector debt must be reduced in this country, and the Australian Labor Party should be honest enough to acknowledge this and to acknowledge its own culpability in creating this situation.

The previous Labor government taxed and it spent. Labor increased wholesale tax and petrol tax, introduced the FBT, raised the pension age for women to 65, introduced retrospective HECS changes, increased the Medicare levy and raised company tax. Despite this, Labor still managed to accumulate $69 billion in deficits over its last five years. As Terry McCrann has stated:
This is the Budget we had to have—and self‐evidently never got and never would have got from the previous occupant of the Lodge.
Another commentator, Alan Wood, has stated frankly:
Labor should apologise for its terrible failure as a financial manager and help Costello clean up the mess.

One of the most disastrous examples of Labor's mismanagement was the running into the ground of Australian National, in my own electorate at the Islington workshops and elsewhere around South Australia and Tasmania. In the 13 years, the number of employees of AN has declined from 10,500 to 2,500. Yet Labor now tries—
Mr Sawford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Port Adelaide tries to lay the blame at our feet.
—Exactly.
—How wrong he is.
—Impossible.

—Was he on the government benches in recent years? As recently as yesterday the opposition attempted to pretend that this had occurred since the change in government. But they do not fool the workers at AN who know and understand the situation. They know that Labor set up National Rail and that AN had, in the words of one worker, `the guts ripped out of it'. And in the words of another:

BREAK.PARA: If the National Rail Corporation was made to pay its way at market rates, Australian National would still have its original investment which it could use to invest in other areas, such as the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link or other investment which would benefit Australian National, the country and, ultimately, the Australian taxpayer.

There is some good news in the budget for the workers and their families at the Islington workshops and for the residents of my electorate who live nearby. Money is at last available to clean up the badly contaminated land there, and that was confirmed in the House yesterday by Minister Sharp. All this is in sharp contrast to the previous ministers for transport, Senator Bob Collins and the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), who talked on this subject but never delivered.
As the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has also recently commented:
We do not want to condemn Australia to a high debt future, nor put at risk the reduction in interest rates

and the growth that will flow from it. That's the choice. There are no easy choices in relation to the Budget . . . If we don't do it now, future generations are going to have less choice than we had because they are not only going to be trying to pay for their own services out of their own taxes, they are going to be servicing the debts that we ran up on their behalf.

I endorse those comments. They encapsulate the position—that bind, if you like—in which the government finds itself. The coalition has introduced some tough measures, but they are for the future for us all, and to guarantee future Commonwealth credibility in financial matters and the Commonwealth's ability to provide quality services into the next century.

Labor created this mess and now wants to obstruct the very measures that will undo it. In regard to interest rates and business and consumer confidence, this is an especially irresponsible measure. Under Labor, home mortgage rates hit 17 per cent and business loans went over 20 per cent because Labor could not control its spending. As the Treasury secretary has stated, Australia will be `courting danger' by doing anything else but putting into place a sincere and genuine attempt to tackle government debt.

I read with some shock the comments by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) to the effect that the budget was an act of betrayal and the first step towards a new, unfair society. I have gone to some lengths to explain the many fair measures in this budget that give no small amount of attention to ensuring that all sections of the community contribute to undoing Labor's mess—the legacy of its betrayal of Australian taxpayers, the unemployed, the elderly and the battlers.

In speaking on the budget, I cannot let the events that transpired on the eve of the budget go without comment. I was in the position to observe these events first‐hand for one and a half hours as I assisted those who sought to defend this place. Television coverage of the event did much to convey the violence that was apparent that afternoon, but television is a medium that does not easily capture in its entirety the mood that can be present during such an event. I can assure all those who think that the riots were sensationalised or over‐reported that the threat was very real and a pervading sense of fear hung heavily on all those who were present in the foyer that afternoon.

I would like to take this opportunity to place on the record my admiration for the way the Federal Police handled that situation. They were calm under extreme provocation. Damages are now estimated at $300,000 and I hope that those responsible are made to pay. I know that there is extensive video film of the riots and some people have already been identified. One unionist from Adelaide, who authorised such charming election material as the message, `If you believe in religious freedom and human rights, put Worth last,' has been identified as being a ringleader.

In conclusion, I would like to address some of the issues raised during this debate by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I would like to draw all members' attention to the fact that the federal seat of Oxley is one in a desperate position. In many ways, it is a microcosm of Labor's mismanagement. The member for Oxley would do better to address the problems of unemployment and poverty in her electorate than to make overgeneralised attacks on our indigenous communities and bodies like the United Nations. What will negative campaigns do to alleviate the suffering experienced by her constituents?

We have seen only this week the benefit of being part of the United Nations, with Australia sponsoring an anti‐nuclear testing agreement. This will prove beneficial for all Australians, including the constituents in Oxley. But the member would have us leave it. The member for Oxley refers to her research proving that indigenous Australians are better off than non‐indigenous Australians. I have already circulated to my parliamentary colleagues, in July of this year, my own arguments that reveal the shortcomings in her research.

All members on both sides of the chamber are here to represent all sections of the Australian community, and to promote the politics of inclusion and tolerance. It achieves little to concentrate only on negatives and those arguments which seek to divide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in opposition to this budget. In particular, I wish to raise the issue of Grayndler and the impact that this budget will have on my electorate. The people in my electorate have been hurt by this budget. They have been hurt because of the savage budget cuts inflicted on them by the new Howard‐Costello razor gang.

SPEECH.PARA: I was at university the last time the coalition handed down a federal budget. At the time, I believed that the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, was a Thatcherite. In hindsight, he was positively dripping wet compared with his sidekick, the architect of the first razor gang, the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

Mr Howard promised during the election campaign that services to people in need would be maintained. He promised stability and he promised fairness. Obviously, these were not core promises, because what this budget delivers is cuts to services and instability for families across the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—I say to the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), in particular, that this budget probably does represent and deliver for people in St Ives, but their interests are not the same as those of the people in Marrickville.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from making savage and unnecessary cuts to the public sector, higher education, ATSIC and the ABC, what this budget does is to shave off funds from virtually all government sponsored service delivery programs, which will adversely affect people most in need.

Let us look at my electorate. I stated earlier that the people I represent have been hurt by this budget. They are people who can least afford to be hurt. According to the 1991 census, 41.6 per cent of people in Grayndler were born overseas—the Australian average is only 22.3 per cent—and 47.8 per cent of people speak a language other than English at home. The Australian average is 15 per cent. By and large, the working people of Grayndler are wage and salary earners—88.8 per cent.

What effect has this coalition budget had on these people? First of all, the Medicare office in Marrickville Road has been earmarked for closure but, never fear, they are going to put a fax machine in the local pharmacy! It is a pity that this cannot be programmed to assist those residents whose first language is not English, and it is a pity that those who cannot afford to wait for cheque refunds are going to be disadvantaged by this. I note also that there are no Medicare offices on the hit list to close in the seat of Bennelong or in the seat of Higgins.

Secondly, the CES offices are closing. They have been marked off to close at Marrickville, Ashfield and Leichhardt. I guess if you cannot register for work you do not appear in the unemployment statistics.

Just a few doors down from my electorate office is Marrickville Skillshare. This is an organisation which has excelled in getting long-term unemployed people into real jobs. On average, 60 per cent of their clients go on to find long-term employment. Furthermore, Marrickville Skillshare has developed a specialist expertise for people from non‐English speaking backgrounds.

What is their reward for such conspicuous success? The minister responsible, Senator Vanstone, has decimated the Skillshare budget. Its staff numbers have been halved. This time last year Marrickville Skillshare was able to provide six months training and work experience for 45 adults and 42 youths in its brokered programs. Today, the brokered programs no longer operate. It is likely that for this financial year Marrickville Skillshare will be funded to assist 340 clients as opposed to the 800 that it assisted in the last financial year.

Labour market programs are the key to addressing the problem of unemployment in this country but all this government can see is the amount of money that can be saved by cutting them down to the bone. Even if you look beyond the rationalist response; even if you look beyond the human cost of unemployment then you will see that the economic cost is also massive because people, if they are not in jobs, are not paying taxation. Therefore, on the revenue side you lose money and on the expenditure side you are forced to continue to pay out social security rather than people gaining their income from employment. This is policy madness. It will lead to an increase in unemployment and it will also have a long-term negative economic effect.

Moving a little further afield we come to the Marrickville region Adult Migrant English Service situated at Enmore. This time last year AMES was running 15 DEET funded English for Work courses. These courses are by and large taken by highly motivated, newly arrived migrants. The courses themselves are not for the faint‐hearted. There are three levels, each of which involves 20 hours of intensive English tuition over 20 weeks. Upon completion of English for Work III, students would be considered eligible for entry into TAFE vocational courses.

How many courses are currently running today at Enmore AMES? There are two! Last year there were 15, now there are two. Forget the shaving analogy of the budget I used earlier, this is slash and burn. Incidentally, AMES also runs adult migrant English program courses for the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs but from 1 October this year the concessional rate of $2,205 for the English education charge will be scrapped, which means that NESB migrants will have to pay the full charge of $4,405. On 1 January 1997 the charge will rise to $5,500. Currently, some 90 per cent of people who pay the charge are eligible for the concessional rate.

This cost recovery measure inflicts a further financial burden on the very people who can least afford it: new and potential migrants. This is another example of the government implementing an agenda which has played up to the racists in our community, which suggests that those in ethnic communities can go to the bottom of the pile. Perhaps when we see the Prime Minister show some leadership in speaking out against people such as Pauline Hanson he will have some credibility and the people on the other side of the table will have some credibility as well. Realistically, the only migrant groups unaffected by this charge, the only ones that have been left alone, are those from English speaking countries.

There is a lot of rhetoric also from those on the other side about the family. Increases in child-care fees are inevitable given the loss of operational subsidies for community based long day care centres. Families using these centres will be paying around $20 a week more for each child in care. My electorate has 16 community based long day care centres providing places for 756 children. This provides the opportunity for the parents of those 756 children to actively participate in the labour market and provides 252 workers at these centres with employment. All this productivity comes at a cost of only $820,275 in operational funding to the government.

This is peanuts, given the productive value that these parents have for our economy. Community based child care aims to provide affordable, quality care. The prime motive for private child‐care centres is making a profit. Therefore, it is community based child care that sets the standard in the marketplace.

This represents yet another broken promise by the new government. In a letter to the Australian Early Childhood Association, dated 28 February 1996, just days before the election, the then shadow spokesman for family services, Dr David Kemp, made a commitment to preserving the operational subsidies, and I quote:

The policy also states our continuing support for the community‐based long day care sector, and we regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector. The coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy.
It is a very clear commitment that has been broken by those opposite.

I guess this is just another one of those non‐core promises. We had two sorts of promises. There were the ones that the new government kept. They were the core ones. All the rest were the non‐core promises. They do not really count. We will remember that and we will be reminding those opposite of it in the lead‐up to the next election.

The so‐called family‐friendly tax initiative is also fundamentally flawed. A low income family who, by necessity, must have both parents working gets a tax break of only $1,000 per dependent child. Such a family may earn only $70,000 a year, or $35,000 each. However, a single income family can earn up to $65,000—which increases by $3,000 for each additional child—and get the $1,000 per child and an additional tax break of $2,500 if they have a child under five years. Therefore, a family with three young children, struggling on a combined income of $60,000 a year, gets a $3,000 increase in the tax‐free threshold. However, a single income family with three young children can earn $71,000 a year and get the $3,000 plus an additional $2,500 increase in the tax‐free threshold.

The message is very clear. To women in middle‐class families, who can afford that, it is: stay at home. But to those on the lower end of the rung it is: bad luck. There is no equity in this decision. Let us face it: the only people this family tax initiative will assist is upper middle income earners who can afford to live on one income. Low income families, who by necessity must have both parents working, are, in effect, punished.

These tax concessions, along with the cuts to the child‐care sector, are a transparent attempt to get women out of the work force. Women being forced to leave the work force provides a double bonus for the government. Firstly, their departure creates a job vacancy and, secondly, because they cannot afford to be in the work force, they do not register for work and therefore do not appear in the unemployment statistics. Is this the coalition's secret strategy for bringing unemployment numbers down?

Certainly, this budget is not making Australia the clever country. Another area where the people of Grayndler will be hurting is in changes to the higher education contribution scheme and Austudy. Understandably, most families are very keen to see their children succeed. This sentiment is especially strong in first‐generation Australian families, who by and large had very humble beginnings. I remind members that almost half the population of Grayndler was born overseas. One form of relief for these parents was that independent Austudy became available to many students at the age of 21. To raise this to 25 years places an untenable burden on many families. Furthermore, lowering the income threshold for HECS repayments from $28,495 to $20,701 means that many graduates will find it very difficult to get ahead. As a result, they may need to rely upon the support of their parents even longer.

The likely outcome of these changes is that children from lower income families will be forced to give up the dream of a tertiary education because their parents simply cannot afford it. But then, perhaps this is actually one of the aims of these changes. I can assure the Main Committee that, contrary to comments made by Senator Vanstone, not too many students from the inner west of Sydney will be paying their way into university in the `dumb but rich' category that is being implemented by this government.

The privatisation and Americanisation of the Australian higher education system, whereby people from richer areas, from rich families, can buy their way into university, having not got the marks, is a disgrace—given, in particular, that they will have had advantages of going to the sorts of upper‐class private schools that some of the people opposite obviously went to.

The elderly and the frail are not immune from the new, improved razor gang either. There is nothing like hitting people when they are down. The coalition government has withdrawn $88 million from its contribution to home and community care funding. And the government's proposed solution of the shortfall in funds? User pays, of course—user fees for meals on wheels, user fees for home visits, user fees for community transport, user fees for respite care, user fees for shopping support, user fees for home maintenance.

These services allow the elderly and the disabled to remain in their homes with dignity. Without them they will be forced into nursing home care. But of course they cannot really do that, because once they apply to get into a nursing home, having had the choice of staying at home taken away from them, the government begins to impose an up‐front fee of an average of $26,000. This may not be a lot of money for people in Bradfield, but I can assure you that it is a lot for people in Grayndler and it is a prohibitive amount for vast numbers of elderly Australians and their families.

Furthermore, thanks to the budget, people already living in nursing homes face increased fees. This will negatively affect almost 2,000 elderly people currently living in the 34 nursing homes in Grayndler. There are 1,954 people in my electorate who will be impacted by this.

Perhaps one of the most unjust aspects of this government's cost‐cutting plans is the threat to the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement. Funding for the next financial year may remain stable, but it is only while reforms are being worked out. It is clear, however, that these so-called reforms will lead to funding cuts of up to $500 million. The importance of public housing may be lost on the coalition government, but for hundreds of thousands of people across the country it is no exaggeration to say that it is a lifeline. Having grown up in public housing for the first 20 years of my life, I certainly can attest to that.

BREAK.PARA: The government's idea, in effect, is to abolish public and community housing, and to extend rent assistance to public and community housing tenants. In an area like the inner west of Sydney, the rental market is very tight and market rents are very high. You would be lucky to rent a bed‐sitter for less than $100 a week and an average three‐bedroom home would rarely be leased for less than $300 a week. Such a change would alter the whole character of inner city areas, where public housing has ensured that there is a mix of people of different backgrounds. Even with increased rental assistance, low income families will be severely disadvantaged by the loss of public and community housing. The effect of these changes is potentially devastating to low income families. But then it seems clear to me that when the Prime Minister and the Treasurer talk about family friendly initiatives they do not include lower income families.

In conclusion, this budget will increase inequality. It is a road which has been gone down before; it is a road which Margaret Thatcher went down in Britain, and Reagan and Bush went down in the United States. But it is a road which is being rejected all over the world. The UNDP's Human Development Report, which came out this week, when comparing economies throughout the world said:

. . . the key to East Asia's success was a relatively equal distribution of private and public assets. Countries there concentrate on redistributing not income but wealth. What generates income is productive wealth. A progressive redistribution of assets tends to boost growth because it has a broad positive effect on people's incentives.

There is also a report by the OECD that came out in July 1996. This report concluded that growing inequality is far from conducive to growth. It admits the future prosperity of OECD countries depends on reducing social and economic exclusion in the forms of high unemployment, non‐participation in the labour market and, in some instances, growing inequalities in earnings and incomes. The World Bank has also put out a report suggesting that growing inequality is bad for economic growth.

I would suggest that the results of this budget are very much going to be a reduction in economic growth, an increase in unemployment and an increase in inequality in our society. When you look at the labour market programs, where you have a strategy implemented to have labour market programs withdrawn, you also have changes to the social security system with massive proposed increases in penalties for people. If you do not turn up to a job interview, you can cop up to at least 13 weeks withdrawn social security payments. Some of the honourable members around this House should think about what they would do without 13 weeks of any payment. Those people have to get their money from somewhere.

This is not a `fair go' budget as the government would like us to believe. It is a `have a go' budget. Have a go at the elderly. Have a go at the unemployed. Have a go at low income families. Have a go at women. Have a go at students. And have a go at people least able to fight back. I urge the House to reject the measures in this budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence I would have to refute some of the nonsense that was just said by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese). The best study on income distribution in Australia was done by Boyd Hunter and Bob Gregory from the Australian National University. Bob Gregory was a member of the Reserve Bank Board. From 1978 to 1991 the top five per cent of income earners in this country increased their average income by 23 per cent. The bottom five per cent reduced their average income by 22 per cent and, in fact, the people who were displaced most from the work force were women in low socioeconomic areas and blue-collar workers. This budget, amongst other things, actually does a great deal to try and reduce income disparity in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the period leading up to the March federal election I was asked by a number of people why I was in such a hurry. I replied that this election was occurring at a time when, in every sense, our country was at a turning point in its history. As such, I do not consider that the election was a cricket match to which we would return in three years time, nor was it a question of whether John Howard or Paul Keating would occupy the Lodge for the ensuing three years, but rather, the outcome of the election would see the economic and cultural destiny of Australia set for the next 30 years.

This budget represents the first of what will be a series of major changes in direction for Australia. In its broader sense, it heralds two fundamental shifts in the way that we see ourselves. The first is to set a three-year program to turn the deficit into surplus to stop indulging the present generation at the expense of our children. In returning expenditure to a level below that of income and consolidating this nation's capital base, we begin the long road back to funding social infrastructure from income rather than from the accumulation of further debt in the sale of assets including the acquisition of Australian companies by foreign interests.

The second major change and arguably the greater change to be found in the budget papers is a cultural shift. Under the previous government, in particular, the expectation of what governments can and will provide had grown at an unsustainable rate. This budget represents the first instalment on rediscovering the forgotten ethic of those who can afford it being encouraged, if not expected, to care for themselves, whether that be in health, aged care or higher education.

The opposition parties, and the Labor Party in particular, cannot seem to make up their minds. On the one hand, the shadow Treasurer, suffering from relevance deprivation syndrome, certainly publicly, and I suspect also within the Labor Party, agrees to a three‐year strategy for deficit reduction, but on the other, thinks that $7.2 billion in savings should be obstructed. As Alan Wood, in the Australian on September 10, said, Labor seems intent `on extending its record of fiscal irresponsibility into opposition, aided and abetted by the Australian Democrats.'
For every billion dollars of budget savings blocked by the opposition, another billion dollars has to be raised on the international equity markets or through the sale of Australian assets.

In debating this budget, this parliament needs to put our circumstances into proper perspective. We have had external deficits in 28 of the last 30 budgets. Sixty‐nine billion dollars was accumulated in deficits by the previous government's last five budgets. Household savings at 2.5 per cent of disposable income are the lowest in the OECD and the lowest savings ratio in the developed world. We have a lack of savings, public and private, which has meant that growth approaching 3½ to four per cent has required us to use monetary policy and increase interest rates to stop a balance of payments problem, with people who are left trying to manufacture in Australia having to borrow money offshore in order to support growth.

The use of our debt under the previous government to prop up consumption has exposed us to an exchange rate depreciation. Four per cent of our gross domestic product has been spent servicing debt and equity obligations. Net foreign debt approached 40 per cent of GDP and, under the previous government, debt reached a staggering 19 per cent of gross domestic product. If you then look at Eslake's work on social security payments, he found that, in 1970, 18 per cent of Australians over the age of 15 were in receipt of some kind of social security payment. In 1995, 30 per cent of the people in this country over the age of 15 were in receipt of social security payments, and if you excluded unemployment benefits it was 24 per cent.

Last year we spent more on health, welfare and education than all of the money raised by taxes on income—and that is PAYE taxes paid by the attendants in this chamber and by people in blue‐collar areas, like that of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), who are out there working today. I repeat: more money was spent on those three big‐ticket items than all of the money raised on taxes from income. The amount spent last year on health, education and welfare was $71.3 billion. In contrast, $65 billion was raised by taxes on PAYE income earners.

You cannot have it both ways. You cannot snuggle into bed with two to three per cent underlying growth, denying transport, communications and industrial relations reform on the one hand, and then, on the other, insist on free education, health and aged care. The Labor Party's history of opposition to serious tax reform completes a picture of disengaged unpreparedness for the realities this nation now faces. Little wonder the shadow Treasurer's accurate self‐diagnosis of relevancy deprivation syndrome! Let's hope it is not contagious—for the member for Port Adelaide at least.
This budget finally moves Australia in the right direction. In the 1995‐96 budget, the deficit, as we now know, was $10.5 billion. That is 2.1 per cent of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Third lowest in the world.
—In the 1996‐97 budget, we will now move to $5.6 billion deficit or 1.6 per cent of GDP.
—The second lowest in the world.

—In 1997‐98 we will go to a $1.5 billion deficit—0.3 per cent of GDP—and in the following year we will return to a surplus of just under $1 billion. What the member for Port Adelaide fails to appreciate is that in those other countries that have those levels of debt they also have high levels of growth, they have high levels of savings and they also have positive balance of payments. What this means to us, to everyday Australians, is a return to surplus, an effective long term improvement to national savings and to a deep‐seated balance of payments problem and, along with industrial relations reform, unshackling of the impediments to growth.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important aspect of the budget that needs emphasis is a charter of budget honesty. For the benefit of members on the other side, honesty means that you actually tell the truth, that you tell people what the facts are. The charter of budget honesty requires that the heads of the Department of Finance and Treasury will sign off on an economic and fiscal outlook within 10 days of the election being called. After the election is announced, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition can request costings of their announced policies by heads of the Departments of the Treasury and Finance. It requires annual updates on the government financial position and economic outlook. Every five years the government will have to publish an intergenerational report which assesses long term sustainability of its policies. It will require a fiscal strategy statement to be produced annually and, of course, we will move to accrual accounting.

In terms of the effect of this budget on my own electorate, I have the privilege to represent the highest median income area in Australia and, in response to the nonsense to which we were just exposed from the honourable member from Grayndler, I can say that I have had a number of concerns in my electorate about the impact that this budget will have on higher income earners. But most people in my electorate seem prepared to accept this if they believe it is in the best long‐term interests of their children and of this country.

I would like to present to the parliament a survey which I conducted of my electorate. It is called the Bradfield Community Survey. I conducted this survey in January and February of this year, and I have some interesting results to present in relation to this budget address. I seek leave to have the survey results tabled and to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Question 4

TALK.START.PARA: —The survey was distributed to the households in my electorate and required those who responded to place it in an envelope, put a stamp on it and mail it back to me. I received 1,285 valid responses. There are another 60 people who did not identify themselves, and so I did not include them in the survey. The survey was made possible through funding provided by the members of the Liberal Party in my electorate; and for their hard work and sacrifice I am extremely grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: When asked to specifically rank 12 listed national issues in order of greatest importance to them, 11.4 per cent of respondents nominated foreign debt as the highest priority; 10.9 per cent, taxation reform; and 10.3 per cent, health care financing reform. But analysis of the responses showed that there was a significant proportion of residents who considered—correctly, in my opinion—foreign debt, taxation reform, interest rates and unemployment to be issues where both the problem and the solution were interdependent.

I should also point out to the House that, whilst a code of ethics for parliamentarians rated a 12, a significant number of respondents explained that, although they were placing it last, in their opinion the ethical and professional behaviour of federal parliamentarians would be likely to substantially improve when the then Prime Minister finished his term. Question 4 invited respondents to nominate the single most important issue that I should address on their behalf, and 265 respondents rated economic productivity issues as the highest priority to them, followed by health, social services, social justice and youth unemployment.

I also advise the House that, in analysing the more specific responses to this question, I was struck by the concerns shown by Bradfield residents not only for the economic indices, but also for a higher priority to be placed on what might be loosely described as social justice issues. Amongst these, permeating the survey was a concern for Aboriginal reconciliation, foreign aid, community service and the treatment of carers, the despair of young people, and what could be described as the compassionate manifestations of the elected government.
