Some of the calls that I have received in my office in the last few months have related, in fact, as much to those sorts of issues as they have to economic ones.

The most interesting part of the survey was the specific comments that people made. I have 160 pages of comments in my electorate office. I read every survey before it was collated into the computer, and I then listed five pages of specific comments from people in my electorate which reflected a cross section of their views and concerns. I will now highlight some of these responses, because I believe that they confirm that, in a general sense, the budget is moving in the direction in which my constituents would like to see us go.

The following are quotes from my own constituents. `I feel powerless as I see Australia slipping downhill.' `. . . working for the good of Australia and Australians on a long‐term basis rather than on an ad hoc basis geared to the next general election.' `Population growth: do we need to grow? Can we sustain growth?' `The question that needs to be asked is: does Australia need multiculturalism? We are not being asked; we are being told that it is good for us. I question that.' `I have been disillusioned with the political process and its participants, short‐term perspectives and constant criticism of the opposition, irrespective of what is good for the country.' `No private enterprise could exist if managed the way this country has been in the last 20 years. Change it and make decisions.'

Other responses included the following. `Develop and rediscover hope in people's lives. Give incentives so that effort is rewarded and they can achieve their dreams.' `We desperately need support for small business: simplification of rules governing small business to encourage employment, and simpler tax for casual or part‐time workers. There are too many rules and regulations covering the simple exercise of doing a day's work.' `Unless we rectify economic issues first, the nation cannot afford to rectify quality of life issues'—and therein lies the fundamental difference between us and the opposition party. `Let's get the country back on a sound financial footing first. You cannot have quality of life in a sick economy.'

The responses continued: `The issue I rank above all those listed is the increasingly inequitable income distribution in Australia, such that the rich are getting richer and the poor are becoming more numerous and poorer. We face a bleak future if this trend is not reversed.' `There should be a long‐term bipartisan plan for Australia, not three years stumbling from election to election.' `An economically strong Australia will benefit all its citizens.' `We are living beyond our means. We must cut spending under our present government.' `Introduce a GST—we are currently taxing all the things we are trying to encourage.'

`The plight of our Aborigines is a national disgrace. It is embarrassing that so many Aboriginal people do not even have access to basic needs.' `Has Australia really become an Asian country? Where are we heading? Are we acceptable to the rest of Asia? How must our people change?' `Industrial relations: there must be a proper balance between capital and labour. Each must cooperate with the other and bloody‐mindedness exists on both sides. Our national future depends on cooperating effort.' `Make unemployed people work for the dole, for example helping in nursing homes, gardening for the aged and other community programs.'

Further responses included: `The problems facing self‐funded retirees are becoming overwhelming. We are treated almost with contempt. We urgently need tax relief, support with private health insurance and concessions available to government funded pensioners. Why is it that you work all your available years and are taxed, try to save and you are taxed, then retire because you have made an effort to save, do not get a pension and still get taxed?'

`We have the tragedy of family break‐up due to the ease with which the young can obtain support from the government, and we parents are told that it is none of our business when we appeal for help. Amongst numerous families I know in this predicament, my own daughter left home at 15 years. She was at a private school—paid by us—but still managed to get Austudy on two occasions when stopped by us. In the three years away she has managed to live on welfare, jobsearch allowance, workers compensation—obtained after one week's work—and other handouts which she wastes on trivialities, including cigarettes and alcohol. A group of them move from place to place and therefore do not pay any rent. It annoys us immensely that this child earns more than I do a week, as I work part time, have eight certificates and a degree. My husband is too busy trying to survive in business to tell you what he thinks. Do the best you can.'

The responses continued: `The only way anyone will employ young people is if there is a youth wage.' `I wish to live in a just society with equal opportunities for all. It may surprise you that I do not mind paying taxes to bring this about.' `What a welcome relief for someone to ask my opinion.' `The total negativity of one political party to the other is appalling. The TV picture of abuse and name‐calling is so pathetic and we refuse to watch it. See if you can bring some decency and respect back into federal politics.' `The country has no hope, the way things are going.' `If you are going to pursue politics do it with passion and not platitudes. Make the tough decisions and not the politically expedient.'

The responses included also: `Youth suicide: concentrate on the needs and welfare of our young men and women, particularly, and give them hope.' `Please oppose republicanism. We believe this overrides all the abovementioned issues.' That was a comment from a household of eight people aged 9 to 89. The next respondent said, `The republic: I will not vote Liberal because of the attitude to a republic. Liberal policy has to broaden its appeal.'

So on it goes. These are people in my electorate expressing their own concerns, their own aspirations for Australia, and this was at a time immediately prior to the election. It was a time when we were labouring, if you like, under the previous government. Therein lie many of the reasons why there was a change of government and the reasons why the people wanted to see change.

I know that the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) yesterday described me as `the silvertail doctor'—I wish I were a silvertail—`from the Upper North Shore of Sydney'. But the aspirations and concerns of the people in my electorate are in many ways little different from those of the people in Grayndler or in Port Adelaide. They were desperately concerned about the way our country was going, and they really felt that, while there were many decent people in the previous government, the government in almost every sense had lost its way. To refute the idea that everyone that I represent is wealthy and affluent: I will never live in a three‐storey mansion, I will never own a Rolls Royce, but I will fight to the death for the right of any Australian, whether they live in Grayndler, or Bradfield, to believe that one day they might be able to do that.

The budget is about those two things, as I said earlier. It is also about us stopping indulging ourselves. Of course, in many cases we would love to fund not only the things the opposition is concerned about but also much more; but we can only spend what we earn. Every time we spend more than we are earning, we are spending the future savings of our children, we are forcing people in the private sector to borrow money from overseas, and we are continuing the pressure to continually sell Australian assets. On this issue, by the way, of the electorate that I am privileged to represent, one respondent said to me, `Remember that there is an underclass on the North Shore and that we are hidden, but we are trying to live with dignity on social welfare.' I am very much aware of that fact.

I commend the budget to the House. It is going to do two things. It will return us to the position we were in pre‐Whitlam, which is that our social infrastructure will be funded on income rather than on debt. It will, as I said before the election, also change the destiny of this country. We now have a Prime Minister who is like any one of us, an ordinary man, a man who clearly is relating the decisions that he and the government make to the concerns and aspirations of people in my electorate and people in the electorate of Grayndler and of Port Adelaide. He is someone who is obviously taking into account what we think when he makes a decision on our behalf. Those of us who are privileged to be members of this government will do everything that we can to see that the voices of our constituents are being heard, whether we happen to agree with them or not. I commend the budget to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1996 budget represents a continuation down the path of the downsizing of government involvement in the economy that has been at the heart of economic thinking in this country for more than a decade. However, this government has taken the credo a step further in what I believe are its misguided endeavours to balance the budget inside of two years. Let it not be forgotten: the so‐called $10 billion Beazley black hole is about one‐third of the Howard cosmic catastrophe left in 1983, yet that was brought back into balance, as indeed can this deficit be controlled more conservatively, and with less disruption, than this budget allows.

SPEECH.PARA: In the desperate rush to win credit ratings from the money markets, we have slashed any meaningful commitment to many of the long‐term unemployed and to regional development, Aboriginal reconciliation, alternative energy development, and our national broadcaster. We have premised any environment commitment upon the sale of our greatest earning asset; which sale will provide, for the huge environment problems we face, less funding than has been provided in normal outlays in forward estimates in recent years. Middle Australia has been provided with a tax break, on the one hand, but has been asked, on the other hand, to fork out more for child care; while dental programs for the disadvantaged and elderly have been dismantled.

First, let us examine the labour market programs. New employment placement enterprises will now be paid on the basis of their success in getting unemployed job seekers into sustained employment. While this new market driven labour program is attractive to free marketeers, the payment structure will, according to the budget papers, `be focussed on finding people jobs rather than placing them in training programs.' What a wonderful motherhood statement! Will this mean that the displaced power workers, the road workers, and the defence factory workers of the Lithgow district, for example, will be delivered into new jobs? Where, I ask, will these new jobs come from? The government has set no target on reducing unemployment, and most indications are that it will sit at around eight or nine per cent for the foreseeable future.

So where, I ask—as we downsize Telstra even further by 23,000 jobs, as we become even more efficient for the sake of fewer and fewer—are these jobs that these entrepreneurs of the unemployment marketplace are to deliver? PEPEs, those private employment enterprise centres, look set to be the boom growth industry of the late 1990s. For what results? At a time when there are few jobs emerging in regional Australia, our government has chosen to slash back its commitment to regional development—surely the catalyst for growth and job generation.

To expect a balanced budget to deliver lower interest rates and then, by some magic, a growth in job investment, is pure fantasy. The transport and regional development sector of these budget papers is shameful. Apart from a commitment to maintain a bipartisan agreement on the Pacific Highway funding, nearly every category is a negative. That is a cut in regional commitment. Let me list just three of them: a $132 million reduction over four years in funding for the national rail infrastructure authority; a massive reduction in funding for the national highway system; and abolition of the regional development program which has been severely criticised by local government, farming, commercial and community groups around Australia. At a time when regional Australia is crying out for infrastructure assistance, this government is turning its back.

When the minister announced the RDOs were being cut, I said I looked forward to his commitment of projects of `real and lasting benefit to regional Australia.' Where are they? A political handout of $48 million has been provided, in such excruciatingly tight fiscal times, to the South Australian Liberal government for Adelaide airport. Let us analyse this. Given that Adelaide airport's performance is declining, how does this government find $48 million to extend what is one of the country's lowest ranked airports—being neither a major tourist destination nor having any significance as a freight airport—to link into south‐east or north Asia?

Adelaide is primarily a domestic airport. In the financial year 1995‐96 it handled just 230,000 international passengers—just two per cent of the national total—while at 6,554 tonnes of airfreight exports in calendar year 1995 it barely exceeded three per cent of the national total. Yet this government has found $28 million this year, and a further $20 million next year, to fund Adelaide airport runway extensions. At a time when we need to be funding—and when both sides of politics promised—at least a feasibility study of a new freight airport at Parkes, this government has provided zero, zilch, nothing, to a project that potentially could deliver many hundreds of jobs and billions of export dollars from goods delivered efficiently to our markets to the north. It is difficult to see what benefits will flow to Australia from $48 million worth of Adelaide airport extensions—certainly not a huge leap in international passenger traffic or airfreight export from an airport ranked below Cairns in importance.

This budget has also sold out any real commitment to alternative energy research. The fledgling ethanol fuel industry, of which the Manildra group was a major player until budget night, has rightly challenged statements by energy minister Senator Parer who claims, `current production and use of fuel ethanol is not cost effective in reducing emissions of greenhouse gas and environmental pollutants.'

The axing of the bounty, due to be in place until the year 2000, saved the government $21 million. That bounty has helped attract more than $40 million in private sector investment in viable production of fuel ethanol through the processing of feedstocks. The ethanol bounty scheme also provided $4 million for research and development of processes to produce ethanol from forest plantation thinnings, sawdust, crop stubble, cotton trash and biomass from urban waste, among others.

That research and that 18c a litre bounty have been stopped dead in their tracks. Along with the government's refusal to endorse the greenhouse emission targets that the rest of the developed world demand, this decision displays a lack of environmental concern, policy that suits the petroleum industry, and a guarantee that if our economic direction may no longer be that of a banana republic—although I have doubts about that—our environmental record is certainly heading that way.

Since World War II, government subsidies to the oil industry are estimated to be $2.9 billion. Against this is the $25 million under the ethanol bounty scheme, $3.9 million in associated research and development, and $2 million for a pilot ethanol program. Yet the Australian Institute of Petroleum complained that the bounty would give ethanol an unfair advantage. Major oil companies refuse to participate in the bounty scheme, but 100 independently owned service stations have been supplying ethanol blend fuel in Sydney and regional areas. The dark shadow of the oil giants lies right across this disgraceful budget decision.

Such also are the environmental credentials of a government that wants to flog off our most valuable asset on the spurious grounds of setting up an environmental heritage trust, which could easily be funded by accessing that very Telstra dividend indefinitely. The Telstra sale is not about the environment; it is a continuation of the shameful disposal of our national assets begun by that champion of national sovereignty, Paul Keating, and embraced with passion by the Liberal Party. The National Party has tagged along with this economic lunacy, too timid to argue against, and now enmeshed in the sticky web of, downsizing and sell‐offs to explain to its bewildered and angry constituency why government and former government services and publicly owned enterprises are disappearing before their eyes. To dispose of Telstra, delivering $2.3 billion to its shareholders—the people of Australia—is short‐sighted economic vandalism.

Let us turn to the elderly and how they may be treated by this budget. The changes to nursing home contributory funding—the shift of costs from government to the public—must be better explained to an older generation that has yet to be fully consulted about the implications for the family home, the inheritance that all older people want to hand on to their children. Such cashing‐up of assets to pay for nursing home accommodation also dramatically underlines the physical cut these elderly people must make from the life outside to that within an institution.

Chances are that many families may choose to try and keep their frail elderly in their homes and try to provide less than professional caring. I hope there is no plan here to ease the demand for nursing home beds. The Thatcher government introduced a similar scheme—the cost was debited to the elderly patient's estate—that brought about a huge increase in home care, with disastrous social results, but delivering the desired cost shift from the government to the patient or their family.

But having said that, I must report that one local community body in my electorate, the Yeoval Multipurpose Health Centre, containing as it does a nursing home, hostel and hospital, sees real benefits in obtaining such funding from local clients to enable maintenance and extensions and improving a facility for the benefit of local elderly people, who will, in fact, be investing in a community asset, ensuring its continued viability and caring for older people within their own district, rather than their being forced to seek nursing accommodation in some more distant town.

This is perhaps one of the unintended and unsuspected positive outcomes of this new policy for more remote towns and communities. But it certainly needs widespread explanation and consultation before it is implemented, because there is a concerned sector of the elderly population in larger centres, such as Orange, Bathurst and Lithgow, who see this is an assets grab for little apparent return. Having paid taxes in the past to support aged care, they are now being asked to pay for their own.

Mr Deputy Speaker, while mentioning the Yeoval Multipurpose Health Centre, might I plead with the government to research this model of what smaller centre health care should be all about and to maintain federal commitment to the multipurpose centre biannual grant program. The Yeoval community have been successfully conducting their multipurpose health centre for seven years, and they firmly believe the concept is one that suits rural and remote areas. So do I.

BREAK.PARA: Throughout my electorate there is grave concern at the abolition of the dental health program, to save this government $55 million alone over the next 12 months and $112 million, $114 million and $116 million in each of the three years after that. The Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge) said in the House that it was a very difficult decision, but cuts had to be made. He said that it was a program that had handled the backlog and was now to cease. Why, then, was there no money set aside for the years ahead? Do underprivileged and elderly people's teeth stop rotting now that the backlog has been met?

In the Orange, Cowra, Lithgow and Bathurst health districts, there is a six‐month waiting list for people to access the program. That was before the budget. Emergency care only is being offered from now on. Over 20 per cent of the population will now be denied this assistance; 74 per cent of dental health funds for the economically deprived have gone; four clinics in the region will close. It is a service for which there is no substitute except a dramatic decline in dental health care for disadvantaged young, adult and aged.

The Commonwealth sought, and gained by referendum in 1946, the power to make laws for the provision of `hospital benefits, medical and dental services'. In his policy launch of 18 February this year, the Prime Minister vowed to `continue an effective social security net for the disadvantaged and needy and to maintain all current Commonwealth concessions' which includes dental concessions. Half a million people access this scheme. If it is discontinued there will be waiting lists three years long by 1998 and after that these people will be forced to have their teeth extracted. The state cannot pick up the huge funding shortfall to deliver these services.

Changes to the higher education contribution scheme could also impact heavily on my electorate and rural Australians. While I have no great problem with a modest incremental increase in the contribution to tertiary education by its beneficiaries, the steepness of these increases will particularly hit remote and distance education students from institutes like the Orange Agricultural College.

The cost of $4,800 or thereabouts for rural science and marketing degrees will prove too expensive for many rural students coming from somewhat depressed areas in the bush, trying to upgrade their skills in a rapidly increasing competitive agricultural marketplace. I have fears, too, that the dramatically increased HECS will turn many economically disadvantaged away from tertiary training generally, and their skills could be lost to the nation.

I applaud the extension of the actual means test on Austudy to catch those rorting the system through manipulation of their taxable incomes. It is a patently unfair system which excludes many deserving students with honest parents while including children of families that have prodigious wealth. Why can't part of the savings in the higher education area be directed into more Commonwealth scholarships for the lower income groups, complete with living away from home allowances—a scheme that worked so well in the 1950s and 1960s and offered a transparently fair income tested access to university for thousands of young Australians? One thousand such scholarships for rural and remote area students is a start, but it must be multiplied twentyfold and offered to students right across the spectrum.

Those who can pay should assist more; those who cannot must be assisted in far greater numbers than this budget provides. Otherwise, we will fail to tap the intellectual resources of young people trapped by the economic circumstances of their parents.

The cutbacks to Aboriginal funding—the ATSIC slashes—have been well documented. This country has debated Aboriginal welfare for decades. We have patronised indigenous Australians for generations and only in the last decade has any semblance of self‐determination, apart from Wave Hill, emerged. Yet, at the start of so‐called reconciliation with the first Australians, we have buckled to impatience, ignorance and mischief at best, racism and deliberate community division at worst.

We have pulled $400 million from Aboriginal programs. It is one thing to share the budget pain, it is another to devalue both funding and self‐determination. Our spending on Aboriginal programs—$1.5 billion out of $130 billion—is about 1.2 per cent of total outlays, less than the two per cent of the population that Aborigines represent. Let us get this funding priority in perspective.

While the extension of SBS to more regional areas is welcome, the 10 per cent cuts to the ABC in each of three financial years from 1997‐98 and the current thrust to further corporatise this great broadcaster represents an assault on our cultural infrastructure unrivalled in recent times.

I search with hope in these budget papers for a sign of real commitment to regional Australia. I applaud the supermarket to Asia strategy to boost food exports, but I despair at the lack of commitment to any infrastructure designed to get food to those markets. I heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) say:
It is a carefully designed strategy to identify bottlenecks.
I suggest that air freight transport—an exclusive air freight component and an exclusive air freight industry—is an obvious one needing direct support now and not another committee.

I applaud the $115 million funding boost to CSIRO. I applaud retention of the diesel rebate scheme provided that its rorts are attended to. I applaud exceptional drought circumstance funding continuing and rural adjustment funding. They are vital and obviously welcome. I applaud the fringe benefits tax exemptions and the capital gains rollover concessions—a boost to small business that will hopefully be supplemented by amendments to the unfair dismissal laws.

I was pleased to see a $36 million road black spot funding program until I saw the $621 million cut in national highways spending over the next four budgets. A throwaway line on page 158 of the budget statements says:
Funding for national highways has been reduced.

Well, $621 million is a devastating reduction in a country crying out for better roads as our arteries are hammered by heavy road freight that should be on rail. Sydney‐Melbourne rail freight, for example, has dropped from 50 per cent in 1972 to 20 per cent now.

The green corps job scheme is welcome but will soak up but a minute fraction of the LEAP and other former labour market unemployed scheme participants who will not qualify for traineeships—perhaps 60 per cent of our unemployed. A one‐stop employment and social security service will be achieved through closure of CES offices in many areas with resulting net loss of jobs.

The MAATS system of apprenticeship and traineeships is very welcome. But the cost of implementing it will be at the expense of programs for the most desperate unemployed. It seems that the gold medallists of the jobless market will be catered for but the long‐term unemployed will languish, too difficult to train, not potentially productive enough to attract the new bounty hunters of the labour market.

Medicare services will allegedly be improved by closing Medicare offices and asking chemists to take over this complex task complete with fax machines and 1‐800 lines for the old, the ill and the confused. In essence, this budget begins to balance the books. But it is too rigorous. In so doing, it creates an imbalance in our society that may well prove counterproductive, socially divisive and uneconomic, particularly for regional Australia.

At a time when we need vision and renewed commitment to publicly funded soft and hard infrastructure this budget takes it away. At a time when we need to support job generation in regional Australia this budget does very little. Australians expect a mix of public and private ownership and investment; a mix of private and public employment. By reducing its own spending so severely and relying on the market place to fill the void, by expecting struggling users to pay more by shifting costs to the states, this government and this budget risk contracting the economy of regional Australia even more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey, Fran, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97 on behalf of the people of McEwen; those families who have battled to make ends meet; the young people denied access to higher education or a job; the farmers who have survived drought and flood, volatile commodity prices and high production costs while competing in global markets; and small business people who have survived high interest rates, mounting compliance costs, unfair dismissal laws within a rigid labour market system and a tax system that actually penalised them for working hard and building up their businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak on behalf of all of these people who, for the first time in more than a decade, have an opportunity to break free from the legacy of disadvantage and dishonesty that has held them back and denied them opportunity. They know that we are entering a new era. This has been recognised by editorial comment throughout the country and is reflected in comments, like those of Terry McCrann, describing the budget as `arguably, the only honest budget in living memory'.

People realise that as a government we have not tried to hide the facts. We have stated right up front what the real problem is—a huge deficit of $10.3 billion with a rising level of debt, including a rapidly rising level of Commonwealth government debt moving over the past six years from $17 billion to $96 billion, an increase of 464 per cent, as a result of policies introduced by the previous government.

The major task facing this government is to reduce that deficit and level of debt in the fairest possible way by providing measures to sustain growth and enable business to begin to thrive, while ensuring that those in real need in our communities are cared for. In order to achieve that, a substantial program of reform is needed.

That is exactly what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has delivered in the first budget of the Howard government—a program of reform to reduce the rising levels of deficit and debt. As the Treasurer said, although we did not create these problems, we have taken the responsibility of fixing them. This will be achieved largely through expenditure savings, some reduction in tax expenditure, and a crackdown on tax avoidance.

The hard decisions needed to begin the repair and reform of our economy are long overdue. People in my electorate are appreciative of the fact that this government is prepared to take strong measures but will do so in a way that is fair, balanced and responsible. There are no increases in income tax rates or company tax rates, nor are there any increases in wholesale tax or petrol excise. This budget offers hope and a revitalised future for our country.

BREAK.PARA: One of the key areas this budget will address is the enormous problem of unemployment that we currently have as a direct result of both monetary and fiscal policies pursued by the previous Keating government. The facts about levels of unemployment are these: throughout the 13 years of Labor government, unemployment reached levels that we have not seen since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

Much is being said by opposition members of late about unemployment targets. I am staggered that these people have the audacity to talk about numbers. Let us put these claims under closer scrutiny. Even though those levels of unemployment were high, they were not the true figure. We know that anyone who worked for a few hours a week was not counted as unemployed, and there were many thousands of people underemployed—working way below their level of qualification or getting only part‐time employment and no opportunity to start a career. On top of this, thousands of people were shunted from one training program to another, the only outcome being placement in yet another training program, but no job.

The opposition constantly refers to their Working Nation program as a success, but the reality is contained in a DEETYA report commissioned by the former government. This report found that Working Nation failed to assist the short‐term unemployed, that it neglected the newly long‐term unemployed, and above all, it found that labour market assistance had been changed from inexpensive programs with good outcomes to expensive programs with poor outcomes.

It is the height of hypocrisy for these people, who were responsible for such failed programs, to criticise our government—after only months in office—for the unemployment levels that they created. It is also hypocritical for the opposition now to be demanding targets for unemployment, when even the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said in 1993:

Our commitment, as a government and as a nation, should not be any arbitrary unemployment number or rate. Our commitment must be to the reduction of unemployment as rapidly and as completely as possible.
The Leader of the Opposition knows in his heart that setting targets for unemployment is not the main responsibility of government; it is to actually tackle the causes of unemployment.

The opposition's claim that they could have achieved an unemployment rate of five per cent by the turn of the century is a fairytale. Setting targets does not create jobs. The reality of the situation is—the people of McEwen recognised this on 2 March—that Labor's policies over the past 13 years have been the cause of unemployment, not the cure for it.

Let us examine how the previous government destroyed people's chances of employment. They used monetary policy to create such a depressed economy, where small business—our major employer group—battled high interest rates and lack of consumer confidence. We saw record numbers of business bankruptcies. Those who managed to survive those conditions then had to contend with unfair dismissal laws which resulted in thousands of small businesses ending up in court. An unfair provisional tax uplift factor, high compliance costs and a mountain of paperwork all restricted the ability of small business to become more competitive, more productive and more profitable—the very ingredients needed for growth and jobs. This budget removes those impediments.

An amount of $180 million will be delivered back to provisional taxpayers because this government has already honoured its commitment to reduce this uplift factor of six per cent. This means that we have ended Labor's unfair practice of assessing small business for provisional tax on an income in excess of what they have earned. We have introduced legislation to end the unfair dismissal laws of the previous government. Small business will once again begin to employ people because they will not be penalised for doing so.

The impact of capital gains tax in small business has been a serious issue for a very long time. The previous government had the Beddall report on small business for six years but did nothing. That report recommended major changes to tax—including capital gains tax—on small business, but it sat and gathered dust.

Once again, this government has demonstrated its commitment to small business by introducing in this budget changes to capital gains tax, allowing profit to be rolled over in order to encourage small business to become bigger. It also allows those small business people—who have risked their capital, worked hard, supported themselves, provided employment for others and used their business both to provide a livelihood for themselves during their working life and to build up a nest egg for their retirement—to be exempt from capital gains tax up to a capital gain of $500,000.

This budget also provides encouragement for employee shares as a form of savings through more generous tax treatment. All of these measures are designed to get government off the back and out of the pocket of small business and allow them to thrive in a more flexible economic and labour market environment.

The Australian electorate must be aware that the very people who, when in government, sat and did nothing to help small business employ more people are the same people who, in opposition, are crying crocodile tears about unemployment levels while preparing to vote against our measures of reform in this budget. In other words, they did precious little themselves while in 13 years of government and have now set a course of action to prevent this government from making the changes that they failed to make.

We were elected to tackle this problem. People said that they had had enough of being told that this was as good as it gets, when all around they were confronted with the reality. In country towns and suburban shopping centres there were vacant shops that had previously supported a family and provided local employment, factories forced to reduce shift numbers, and farms that could no longer afford to employ. There was a massive shift from productivity to dependency as the CES list grew and numbers of social security recipients grew. That is what this government inherited after 13 years of Labor government.

Those in opposition, the very people responsible for that legacy, are now the ones opposing and criticising aspects of reform that we want to introduce to fix the mess they created. They lack all credibility. However, we will not be deterred. People elected us to implement reform, and this budget is the beginning of the repair process.

This budget marks a turning point for both young and old Australians; for families, for small business in the country and in the cities. Thirty per cent of young people who drop out of school before year 12 have had no option in the past other than to join an unemployment queue. We will change that. This budget makes provision for $187 million for the development of vocational education in schools. This means that young people not suited to, or who do not want to, study at the tertiary level will now be able to begin an apprenticeship at school and get a chance of a career and a job. The Australian Secondary Principals' Association has welcome this initiative by saying:
At long last there is a recognition that vocational education is important to secondary schools and has a crucial place in the secondary curriculum.
Towards the end of the Keating government, the number of young people in apprenticeships had fallen to the lowest level as a proportion of the work force since the 1960s.

This budget sets to repair this situation by appropriating $200 million over the next four years to modernise the apprenticeship system. There are new growth industries like information technology crying out for a highly skilled work force. By providing the funding and making the system more flexible to allow young people to work at multiple sites through group training means that we are providing a modern apprenticeship training system in tune not just with the 1990s but the next century. This gives hope and opens new pathways for young people.

This budget focuses on providing the best results through traineeships, apprenticeships and encouraging businesses to take on employees by providing wage subsidies. This budget, Mr Deputy Speaker, also acknowledges the struggle so many families have had in making ends meet over the past decade by providing assistance to approximately 2 million low and middle income families. Eligible parents will receive an increase of $1,000 to the tax‐free threshold. This means that a single income family with two children, with one under five, will receive an extra $34 a fortnight.

This government has also honoured our election commitment to make private health insurance more affordable to low and middle income families by introducing in this budget a program of incentive payments. From 1 July next year eligible families with dependent children will be entitled to receive an incentive of up to $450 per year paid either as an up‐front reduction in their premiums or as a tax rebate. These two initiatives mean that eligible families with two dependent children who take out private health insurance will benefit by up to $51.90 a fortnight.

We have developed a comprehensive strengthening family strategy to help prevent and overcome family breakdowns. This strategy incorporates measures to support families in times of financial, social and emotional crisis, strengthen relationships and help prevent child abuse, youth suicide and youth homelessness.

Mr Deputy Speaker, families living in regional areas have undoubtedly been the hardest hit by the previous government—even to the extent of many of the farming families in the Seymour district of my electorate being denied access to drought relief. At a recent meeting of farming families from this region they readily acknowledged that they could do little to affect global commodity prices. What they want and have been trying to achieve throughout the Labor years of government is a reduction to their costs of production and to be able to operate in a more flexible labour market. They are sick to death of having to watch their products—which have been produced using the most cost‐effective means available to them—leave the farm gate and lose their competitive edge through the high costs of transport and fuel, and then face delays and further high costs on wharves due to inefficient work practices.

This budget recognises the importance of regional areas to our national economy and recognises the hardships and special needs of people living in these regions by providing extra assistance for education, health, child care, landcare and road funding.

The Prime Minister's announcement of the supermarket to Asia strategy is a tremendous boost to regional Australia. This not only recognises the advantage we have as well‐ respected producers of clean, green produce from a disease‐free environment and our proximity to the Asian markets, but acknowledges the role regional Australia will play in the future development of value‐added products to an Asian food market estimated to be worth several hundred billions of dollars over the next decade.

This future development, however, and the jobs that will be created in the process are dependent on us as a nation being able to harness our natural resources, talent and technology to take advantage of prospective markets. This budget underpins our future success in these areas. Yet again we find an opposition ready to put this development at risk by opposing aspects of this budget.

The extension of the export market development grants for the tourist industry demonstrates a clear commitment by this government to encourage further development of this growing industry and highlights the inadequate response of the previous government to support this growth industry. Already there are tourist operators in my electorate eager to take advantage of this assistance and I can assure members of the opposition that they are watching very closely to see how they vote on this legislation.

I mentioned earlier the advantages Australia has in producing clean, green food—and how important this is to us as a trading nation. We have this reputation because of our clean environment. However, in order to maintain that reputation as well as repair degraded areas, improve our water quality and control weeds and feral animals so that we can increase our levels of production and maintain our marketing edge, we must spend money on restoration of the environment.

This budget makes provision for an additional $158 million over the next four years. But this is in addition to the $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust from the one‐third privatisation of Telstra. Landcare groups in my electorate are already identifying areas in urgent need of repair that will benefit from this. There is $49 million to assist the states in expediting regional forest assessments in order to fulfil our commitment to implement the national forest policy statement. The central highlands of McEwen will benefit from this process. Once the NFPS is implemented, we will at long last have achieved a balance between protection of high conservation value areas and security for our timber industry, which in my area alone contributes almost $20 million to our national economy and over 600 jobs in the local area.

Young people between the ages of 17 to 20 throughout McEwen will have the opportunity to participate in Green Corps and demonstrate their support for preserving and maintaining the environment in a very practical way while gaining valuable work experience. It is imperative that this budget be passed as soon as possible to enable us to begin the job of repairing our nation and restoring opportunity to all.

I guess it is not hard to realise why we have been left with such a huge task of repair when the opposition is still not able to face the cold hard facts. Just a few days ago the immediate past Treasurer made some statements that defied all credibility when he said:
Clearly, by the standards of comparable countries we do not have a budgetary problem, and we do not have a government debt problem.

One can only wonder what sort of planet the members of the opposition are occupying. What it does say, however, is that they are continuing to delude themselves, but at the expense of people in my electorate.

This budget is an honest start to begin the long haul of reducing crippling levels of deficit and debt, and restoring confidence. Any attempt by opposition or minor parties to block aspects of this budget places this process at risk. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this budget debate, I want to canvass a number of areas in the budget that relate directly to science and research and development, because I think they are quite critical areas and it is very important that we should highlight what the government has done in this budget to these vital areas of our national infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, as a society we are inclined to take science a little bit for granted these days. Those members who are of my generation will recall that the first lunar landings merited almost a full day of television coverage. There was blanket coverage by the news media of the day, and most of the population was transfixed by the spectacle and gave it a great deal of their attention. Now, I am afraid, this kind of event rates but a few minutes on national television. Indeed, often these things are not covered at all in the United States or in this country because they no longer attract an audience share of comparable size.

This says a lot about the way in which our societies regard science, how they regard innovation and technological change. We live in an era of information overload. I am afraid the advances now come so quickly that the public are almost overcome by the rapidity of that change in the science and technology areas and are no longer able to differentiate it, to attune to it, in a way that they once did when the interval between progress and change was somewhat greater.

There are dramatic effects of that in our economy because those changes in society and technology do lend themselves to substantial gains to our economy, to health, to all of those areas of applied science which we take so much for granted in our everyday lives. But, unfortunately, they do create a climate where budgets can sometimes ignore the impact of these vital areas on our national infrastructure—and this is one such budget. I, for one, believe it is vital that the public are informed about what has occurred here and that the information about the impact of this budget on science and technology and engineering is brought to public attention.

This budget represents a very massive attack on innovation in this country. I think it is important to focus attention on the way in which it has attacked innovation in particular, because that is really what we are talking about. Fundamental research and development, whether it is in the pure or applied sciences or engineering disciplines, is vital to the process of innovation in our culture, and innovation is what leads to growth in national wealth.

Throughout Australia's history we have relied on science, engineering and applied science to deliver the goods for our agriculture, mining, health and communications sectors—a wide range of our national infrastructure. It is on those things that we have accumulated wealth over the last 150‐plus years. Without science, without innovation, we would not have been able to achieve the national gains which we have made. It is vital, if we are to consolidate those gains, that budgets of government recognise, particularly at the national level, the vital importance of science, applied science, engineering and technology in delivering growth for the future.

It is critical to examine firstly the area of reductions in research and development expenditure. They are perhaps the most dramatic or the most obvious in the budget. Some $2.25 billion will be saved over the next four years by a combination of reducing the taxation concession available for research and development from 150 per cent to 125 per cent and by abolishing altogether the syndication package. There has been a very small introduction of new funding under the so‐called start program which will provide some additional funds for research and development, but it is minimal when compared to the dramatic cut which the research and development tax concession has suffered and which the abolition of the syndication scheme has brought about. Those two schemes between them, in their own way, have been responsible for ensuring that Australian industry was brought into the research and development revolution.

Australia has always had a very strong background in public research and development. Our universities, CSIRO, ANSTO, AIMS—that whole range of public sector institutions—have always been at the forefront of world science research and development. Business, on the other hand, has never had quite such a strong commitment. In many cases, it has purchased research and development work from overseas, from parent companies or from other companies who have taken the technological lead. Or, alternatively, it has simply failed to undertake the necessary research and development to ensure that its product line was world's best practice, was at leading edge and was therefore able to grow with the world economy.

The Labor government introduced the very substantial tax concession at 150 per cent. It introduced the syndication scheme to address the questions of those companies who are, in effect, cash poor; they have no current profitability because they are committing so much of their funding as a start‐up company to research and development that they are not in the luxurious position of having to pay income tax which would, of course, mean generating a profit. So, by syndication, they are able to combine with those who do have taxable funds, profitable funds, and therefore have the opportunity to provide a cross‐fertilisation in the industrial and private sector to ensure that new start‐up entrepreneurial firms, vital for growth in the 21st century, are able to take advantage of the tax concessions available and are able to get some public assistance in their research investment.

It is critical to have public assistance at the early stages of this process. I certainly do not believe that we should be providing public support, taxpayer support, to mature, well‐established companies who are able to generate sufficient funds for their own research and development over the longer term. But it is certainly vital that we provide initial start‐up capital and that this is freely available to those who want to engage in early research and development, to get their products started and off the ground—a very good way in which syndication was able to address it.

For longer‐term research for the BHPs, the General Motors, the IBMs or whatever of this world—so long as that research is undertaken in Australia—the 150 per cent tax concession addressed their needs and certainly provided substantial encouragement for the board of directors to provide that funding. So combining those two schemes together creates a very good package. That was reflected in the increasing activity in the private sector research and development field that would have generated substantial gains to Australia in employment, in national wealth creation and in preserving our technological leadership in the Asia‐Pacific region.

We have put all of that at risk by cutting the R&D tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. We are now putting ourselves in the category of New Zealand, for example, where the tax concession was abolished and research and development has dropped dramatically. That is the kind of risk we take. People will compare us with our neighbours, Malaysia and Singapore, who offer 200 per cent concessions, perhaps under slightly more restrictive arrangements, Mr Deputy Speaker, but nonetheless under arrangements which are readily accessible to firms which can easily relocate in this region. I think therein lies a very significant risk to this country.

This government is undertaking a massive experiment in the research and development sector. If they are wrong, if that experiment demonstrates what I suggest it will, then Australia will be a very substantial loser. Research and development funding will go offshore; companies will be dissuaded from embarking on what is a very high‐risk undertaking; they will buy proven research from overseas; and Australia will return to those days when we did not enjoy a substantial lead in this area. I think that is the grave risk of this massive experiment which the government is now undertaking for very short‐term, financial expediency reasons.

When we turn to the other side of the research coin, which is the public sector agencies—CSIRO, ANSTO, AIMS, to name the most prominent three—then, of course, a different historical picture needs to be taken into account. These organisations, along with the universities, have always maintained a very substantial public research sector presence in Australia. They have a great track record. Indeed, all honourable members, I think, would be well aware and proud of the record which agencies like CSIRO have maintained on behalf of Australia over the years.

So how has this government rewarded them? At first, I thought, `Very well.' The budget night speech of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) indicated, to quote him directly, `An additional $115 million will be provided to CSIRO.' My first thought was a very positive one, Mr Deputy Speaker, as I am sure it was for all honourable members. I thought, `What exciting science and research projects CSIRO will be able to undertake with this very massive additional amount of money which this government has provided them!' But, like so many other aspects of this budget, when you begin the examine the fine print, that is when the disasters are revealed. Of course, what the Treasurer did not tell us on budget night—and I suspect that it was a very substantial misleading of the House in that regard—was that the fine print in the budget will take millions of dollars out of CSIRO's available funding and, indeed, over a period of the next triennium and beyond, will leave them $10 million or so worse off than they were before the budget.

How will this occur? It will occur by an increase particularly in the efficiency dividend which now applies to all CSIRO activities. Under the previous government there was a modest efficiency dividend on administration, which was defined as 30 per cent of CSIRO's activities—a very modest efficiency dividend in that regard, which encouraged more efficient administration. That has now been extended to three per cent and it has been extended to cover the whole of CSIRO's programmed activities. That is a very massive withdrawal of funding from CSIRO.

How is the government going to recover the rest of its $115 million additional grant? A new efficiency dividend of asset realisation was introduced to ensure that CSIRO would be required to sell buildings, to vacate premises, to liquidate other assets, which will ensure that a total of some $60 million or thereabouts is also returned to government coffers during the course of the triennium, and along with a few other minor measures, realising a few million each, the government will, in fact, recoup more than its $115 million touted additional investment in CSIRO. This will leave our premier public sector research agency about $10 million worse off as a result of this budget over the course of the next triennium.

Look at the dividends which CSIRO has paid, not necessarily in immediate dollar terms, as this government now requires, but in public sector research terms. We have seen from that organisation, over several generations now, the benefits transferred to industry in the patents taken out and in the innovative and often brilliant public sector research. And how has this government rewarded that organisation? It has withdrawn funds from it in a quite deceitful way, given the Treasurer's initial statement on budget night, which will cost this nation dearly over the next few years.

Similar consequences apply to other public sector agencies, like ANSTO and AIMS, which are now subject to the full three per cent efficiency dividend. So, even though, on the surface of this budget it would appear that there was no immediate or dramatic cutback in those agencies, when you take into account the insidious impact of that three per cent efficiency dividend, they will also be left worse off.

I thought it was a nice juxtaposition to see the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) in a Meet the Press interview the other Sunday morning announcing an increase in the AIMS project of a marine science and technology policy for Australia while cutting 20 staff positions out of the AIMS budget. The net effect will be that an organisation, which even the minister admits has a valuable role to play in helping Australia develop its offshore resources, ocean based resources and other freshwater resources in the fisheries and marine area, will now see its funding significantly cut, with some 20 positions, including eight within the scientific projects area, also going.

At a recent budget debate in the science community following the release of the August budget, the minister admitted that over the last six months he has spent so much time working out how to take money out of the science budget that he has not had time to develop a science policy or vision for this nation. So much of the vision that we saw before the election in terms of election commitments has been breached by this budget that I can understand why the minister now needs to prepare a fresh version of that.

But I suspect that the community, and the scientific community in particular, will imply a vision for this minister in the absence of an articulated vision from him and that vision will be implied by the actions of this budget. We will have to conclude that his vision implies cuts, cuts and more cuts to public and private sector science.

That is the vision for science that we have seen from this government. It was demonstrated within weeks of their taking office when the European southern observatory project was summarily cancelled—again, for short‐term expediency in the budgetary sense but at a long‐term cost to the economic and technological development of this nation.

The information technology industry, to turn to another aspect of our science based portfolio, has also done very badly out of this budget. Although there is some prospect that large multinational companies will benefit from the outsourcing bonanza which we might reasonably expect in 12 or so months time when the next budget is being put into place—because I suspect that this government is heading towards that kind of outcome in next year's budget statement—again, that will be at the cost of our local Australian software suppliers and our hardware suppliers as well.

Those small to medium companies which have taken a very significant lead in Australian information technology over the last few years will now find that, in this budget imposed drought in IT, they have no role to play. Whether they will be around next year to take advantage of the outsourcing opportunities which the government will offer, I very much doubt. I also doubt the value of those potential outsourcing opportunities.

BREAK.PARA: We have a situation now where the government has failed to deliver—in a way, thank goodness—on its promise to cut $1 billion out of IT over the next three years. It has admitted that election promise was totally unrealistic and absurd. But instead it has imposed a freeze on significant IT expenditure which will not only hold back savings in government administration, improvements in efficiency, and service delivery to clients, but will also impose an intolerable burden on small and medium sized Australian computer information technology suppliers, software suppliers, who will now have one of their larger customers simply telling them to go away for at least 12 months.

I do not think that is a realistic position for many small companies; they will simply go under. The multinationals will wait it out and they will be around next year to pick up the large contracts which, I suspect, this government will offer. But this imposed drought, if you like, I also suspect will have a very negative outcome for our service delivery possibilities.

IT now is one of those things that needs to be devolved in the power structure. We need to have individuals and departments making assessments about their own requirements and taking advantage of diversity within an overall framework. I understand that we cannot have anarchy prevailing here, but we certainly need to ensure that we capture the benefits of diversity and that we capture the benefits of innovation in client service delivery. Those are the things which we are in danger of losing in a government mandated whole‐of‐government approach which ensures that those outside government in the international computer companies are able to dominate our Australian industry in a way which is entirely at the cost of Australian companies.

The majors—the EDSs, the IBMs and other like companies—have a valuable role to play in the provision of information technology services. I know a number of the people who operate in Australia on behalf of these companies. They provide a significant service to Australian business and to government, but their role must be clearly defined. It should not be to take over the whole of the operation; it should be to form strategic partnerships with departments where they have a special expertise and are able to offer something for the government to take. I suspect that this is an argument which we will be having next year, and will be a substantial one for this country.

In conclusion, I ask: how has this budget dealt with science? The answer is: very harshly, very unfairly. There is a range of matters that I have not had a chance to talk about. The increase in HECS fees for university students in the science and engineering disciplines will be a severe disadvantage. The massive cutbacks to universities as a whole will undermine our ability to delivery on research and development in the sciences and in the engineering fields. Those areas are quite significant, as are the government's cutbacks in international collaboration. Just to take one example, the program on global change is likely to suffer government cuts in this area, and that will undermine our international reputation as well.

Organisations like Telstra in mere anticipation of privatisation, are dramatically slashing their research activities. Those cuts in the Telstra research laboratories, for example, amount to 250 jobs in less than four years—almost half of their research effort. That is what they are doing while we think about privatisation, while the bill is still before the Senate. What happens were it ever, God forbid, to go through and Telstra actually were to be confronted with the reality of that situation? The whole of that research effort will also be undermined. Even small areas, like Internet access for members of parliament or the provision of these information technology services throughout the government, have been the subject of significant reductions in funding. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97. The people in the electorate of Swan knew this government was about to deliver change, a change for the better. They knew that, while delivering our commitments to ensuring that Australian families were given greater security and greater opportunity, we would have an overriding responsibility to reduce our national debt. They were sick and tired of living on the bankcard and sick and tired of this great country having to do the same. We had to reduce a deficit caused by years of overspending, when money was directed into bandaid measures rather than long‐term goals. The previous government were debt junkies who threw money at their problems and then had to find money to pay for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Swan knew that this government was going to change the way the health system and health insurance were administered. They knew that there would be changes in training and education. They knew that there would be changes to small business regulations. They knew that there would be industrial relations reforms. Superannuants were desperate for help and wanted to be treated as equals. Middle income families wanted relief from being underresourced and overtaxed. They wanted security for their and their children's futures.

The Australian people knew of plans to privatise one‐third of Telstra and of the National Heritage Trust which would begin the long overdue commitment to the environment of this nation. Most of all, Australians wanted the opportunity to pay their own way. They were tired of being on the end of handouts. The electorate of Swan—indeed, the people of Australia—knew that there would be these and many other changes. That is why this government clearly has a mandate to govern in a manner which demonstrates fiscal responsibility and prudent economic management.

The Australian people now want this Howard coalition government to get on with the job that they were elected for. This government inherited an enormous amount of debt, larger than the people of Australia were told by the former government. The $8 billion Beazley black hole was our first shock. Now we are informed that it is more than $10 billion. As part of this budgetary process, this government has committed itself to a charter of budget honesty so that we will see the real figures that a new government inherits rather than the dishonest figures displayed by the previous government.

This budget encapsulates some of the necessary measures for debt reduction. Australians generally do not mind taking the pain if they can see that it is being done for some net gain. The previous Labor government told us to endure the pain and things would improve but we were deceived because things only got worse. The previous government deserted their blue‐collar supporters, who really needed their help at a time when the gap was widening more and more between the well off and the battlers. The net result was that the traditional blue‐collar supporters of the ALP voted with their feet on 2 March and supported this government in their droves because they realised that they had been taken for granted, taken for a ride.

This budget has been well received. The measures have had some criticism from the usual quarters but in Swan I generally have had a most favourable response. The electorate has indicated that they are willing to do their bit and learn to live with some sacrifice if it means a positive outcome.

But this budget is not only about cuts. There also have been increases in many areas and shifts of funds, which often go unnoticed—and unnoticed by the media, as I have had to explain to those in Swan who sought clarification on points in the budget. The Australian people are looking at the long term rather than asking how this will affect them today. That is the reason that this budget has been so well received.

In Swan, youth unemployment was up to 30 per cent. That one‐third of our youth was unemployed was totally unacceptable. At times, 12 per cent of the general population in Swan were unemployed; well above the state's average. This is a disgusting state of affairs in my electorate, given that the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was in the best position to help these people as a former Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and then as the Deputy Prime Minister—but he did not.

I kept hearing over and over again that the unemployed people—the youth and the older people who once upon a time had been able to find a job when they wanted—did not want to go from one training scheme to another and be caught in the bureaucratic labour market program cycle. They wished, at the end of their training, that they could find a job, a real job.

The priority of the previous system of labour market programs was markedly different from that which we envisage for the future. Its priority often seemed to be its own administration rather than a focus on outcomes for clients. It was good at hiding the unemployed. The outcomes of these schemes were not fantastic. The numbers of people who found real jobs at the end of these training programs were not high enough to warrant the huge costs of their operations.

Two‐thirds of the people who went through the Working Nation schemes are still out of work. Some participants of these programs would then go on to further training at another institution, such as a TAFE, and repeat what they had already learned. Clients were course hopping. One example is the number of forklift drivers who were turned out of these sorts of courses for a very limited number of actual opportunities to be forklift drivers.

That is not to say that training schemes are unnecessary. Some of the labour market programs run in my electorate of Swan were very well run and had high outcomes. Let me make it clear that I support training, but by efficient, genuine programs that offer the prospect of real jobs.

I did witness duplication of services at some of the labour market programs in Swan. I saw at first hand the need for some cutbacks. Some courses being run by skillshare were also being offered at the TAFEs and at other tertiary institutions. Some of the courses offered by skillshare were not accredited courses and that made it difficult for some employers to accept clients because they did not have recognised qualifications.

Over the next four years, the $5.4 million‐plus that the government has allocated to labour market and training assistance will help those in the labour market to seek employment in a more performance and output orientated program. I support the implementation of the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system, better known as MAATS, which will be partly funded by a considered reduction in labour market program funds. MAATS is this government's response to the fact that in 1995 the number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships, as a proportion of the total work force, was at its lowest level in three decades.

The previous Labor government deserted the apprenticeship scheme, which has resulted in a dearth of skilled tradespeople. Industry is now feeling the effects. This is demonstrated by the fact that one company in Perth, for example, has had to bring in some specialist welders from the Philippines. Current apprenticeship and training schemes do not allow for the schemes to extend to farriers and blacksmiths, for example. These people, once qualified, have the potential to earn immediately from $60,000 to $100,000 a year in their particular trade, but at the moment most farriers are self‐taught and it is very hard to provide skilled training for these people because there are very few skilled people to train them. The previous system has failed these people by failing to train them properly.

Too frequently in Swan I see the social ramifications of the years of not being able to find a job or be trained. I see the dysfunctional people who have lost their self‐esteem and ego and self‐respect. These effects last for years to come and not only permeate other areas of their lives but also often affect the other people in their lives.

My electorate of Swan is the home of a large section of the West Australian racing industry. As much as there are apprenticeship schemes all around Australia which might have accommodated apprentice jockeys, these schemes have been largely ignored because of the lack of incentive and the lack of funding for quality trainers to take on the right sort of apprentice. The system now has done more to train strappers than potential jockeys. Under the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system this has been corrected, and the right people are encouraged to find training. The new funding for MAATS will make it more attractive for the better trainers to take on these budding heroes of the future. Recently I attended a hospitality awards presentation for apprentices at the Ascot Racecourse, which is in Swan. The participants were working in the industry and they were delighted that this budget had provided new funding for MAATS of more than $200 million over four years. This will take the Commonwealth commitment for apprenticeships and traineeships to some $1.7 billion over four years, which is almost half of the $3.7 billion four‐year training package announced by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Minister Kemp.

I passionately support the removal in our workplace reform package of the Brereton unfair dismissal laws, which have been the greatest disincentive to job opportunities for young people. Together with training reforms and small business reforms, employers will have the incentive which has been missing for so long and which has hurt business and employment in Australia.

An issue which has received support in my electorate has been the changes to the higher education system. Significantly, people welcome the fact that those who were likely to earn more at the completion of their degrees were going to contribute more personally than they did under the previous system. I know of only a few students who object to taking responsibility by contributing to their own education. In the last year, nearly half a million university places were filled across Australia and this simply could not have been done without the funds provided by HECS.

I also support the government's decision to speed up the payback of HECS debts by lowering the income threshold. I was asked by a lawn‐mowing contractor in Swan recently why his $24,000‐a‐year income had to pay for someone to be educated, while a graduate earning $24,000 in the first year or two did not have to pay any extra. I could not really answer this, because it was unfair and inequitable. Now, though, the minimum income threshold is $20,701, and this only attracts repayment of less than $12 per week, which will barely affect the lifestyles of future Australian graduates. Through the changes to the higher education system, this government has addressed yet another situation where those who could least afford to were subsidising higher income earners. Again, it has received the support of my electorate, which I am certain is indicative of other marginal seats in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: That leads me to comment on the health system and private health insurance. This government has made a genuine attempt to make the Australian health system universally available. The private health sector has run down from approximately 60 per cent of Australians being privately insured to the current deplorable state where only approximately 30 per cent are privately insured. The result is that there are fewer places in the public health system because those who could be privately insured do not have the incentive to stay.

To address this, this budget delivers our pre‐election commitment that those who can afford to be privately insured will be encouraged to do so, and those who do not wish to be privately insured and who can afford to will pay more in the Medicare levy. This principle will free up hospital places and facilities for those who are genuinely in need and will have the effect of injecting more funds into our beleaguered health system, which has previously been stripped of this vital capital. Older Australians, families and the less well off can take comfort from such a decision because Medicare will certainly stay to service them.

I am happy to say that for the families of Australia, and the families in Swan in particular, this government has delivered on its commitment to ease the financial burden experienced by so many families. In particular, low and middle income families in Swan with an income of less than $70,000 per annum have welcomed the raising of the tax‐free threshold by $1,000 for each dependent child.

The $6 million over the next three years to increase marriage and relationship education services to the community will contribute to assisting families to stay together. This government is serious when it says that the family is the cornerstone of our society, and we are providing genuine support in the form of these types of budget measures.

It is my honour to be in this Main Committee to endorse the first Howard‐Costello budget which delivers the pre‐election commitments to all Australians. Some tough decisions needed to be made in this budget so that our country can be returned to the status that it deserves in the world community. My belief is that the majority of my constituents in Swan understand and appreciate that these decisions needed to be taken.

However, a government which cynically keeps an eye on the popular polls, rather than on those it is committed to serve, is really a government which lives on the edge and does not deserve the support of the people who placed their faith in it on 2 March. I commend this budget to the people of Swan and to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the greatest challenge for all governments in the industrialised world is to address two basic fundamentals: firstly, the fair distribution of income; and, secondly, the attainment of full employment. This budget does neither. This is a poll‐driven budget but without a coherent game plan. This is a budget without the vision thing. This is a budget with a flawed rationale. This is a budget that encourages processes that divide, exclude and ignore. This is a budget based on ill‐founded assumptions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals say this budget is framed to overcome Australia's biggest problems of debt and deficit. The Liberals tell Australians that the Australian economy is somehow in deep, dire trouble as far as debt and deficit is concerned. What is the real truth about debt and deficit in Australia? According to the criteria of the European Monetary Union, Australia has the fourth lowest debt in the industrialised world. What about the deficit? Australia has the third lowest deficit in the industrialised world. That is the real truth.

BREAK.PARA: Under Labor, Australia developed an economy that was internationally and widely accepted as one of integrity and quality.
