A couple of months ago the Australian economy was confirmed by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as sound. So what is all this nonsense about a budget to deal with debt and deficit? This is an assumption that is clearly wrong.

This is also a government that says its WROLA bill, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, will mean higher productivity which will lead to more employment. It is therefore worth examining that assumption. Over the past 50 years in the industrialised world the following has occurred: capital investment has quadrupled; energy consumption has tripled; productivity has tripled; but—and this is a very big but—employment has grown by only a third. Higher productivity does not lead to higher employment. The government is wrong.

This is also a government that believes in downsizing and that it leads to higher productivity and efficiency. It does not. Its guru, Stephen Roach, said so and has clearly rejected the benefits of downsizing. Corporations and business will not deliver full employment. Why would they? Downsizing does not produce higher productivity. It does increase the unfair distribution of income—the gap between rich and poor simply gets bigger with downsizing.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a budget based on flawed assumptions. The debt and deficit argument is wrong. The higher productivity‐higher unemployment link is wrong. The downsizing link to productivity is wrong. But the wrong‐headed thinking of the government continues. The supposed links of budget surpluses to interest rates is wrong. The claim that privatisation is better than a public sector is wrong.

The Liberals say that Labor's opposition to $425 million of the budget bottom line will risk rises in interest rates. Beg your pardon? Run that past me again. At the end of the 1980s, Labor was running budget surpluses and interest rates were 15 per cent. The Prime Minister's attempt to create a connection between interest rates and surpluses is clearly wrong.

The Liberals say that privatisation works better than the public sector, is more productive and gives greater dividends to consumers. Wrong, wrong, wrong. It is competition, not privatisation, that gives lower prices to consumers.

Labor has never said, and does not say now, that our economy is not without problems. Obviously we have a national savings problem which we addressed with a superannuation scheme. There is also a current account deficit problem, to which curiously I have not heard one reference from the government.

Labor could have achieved a budget balance in the lifetime of this parliament, but without the savagery of this budget's cruelty to vulnerable Australians. The Liberals' budget strategy of taking nearly $8 billion out of the economy will contract growth and employment. And yes, the Liberals admitted it in the budget papers. They project no more than 3½ per cent growth right through to the turn of the century. There is no target for growth, there is no target for employment. As I said, this budget has no game plan. This budget gives no direction.

The Liberals have not got the faintest idea where they are going. And there is the sad irony: they do not know where they are going and there is a great likelihood they will end up somewhere else. The great pity of that scenario is that millions of Australians will be seriously harmed in the process.

By contrast, Labor's budget strategy would have achieved a balance in 1998‐99. Labor would have had growth of 4 per cent over the next three or four years. Under Labor that would have meant more jobs; under Labor that would have meant more private income; under Labor that would have meant more savings; and under Labor that would have meant more government revenue.

The reasoning in the Liberal's budget is flawed. It is a blatant betrayal of the ordinary working people of this country, who will pay for this failure. The budget will do nothing for what the Prime Minister said before the March election was Australia's most pressing problem, that of unemployment. By the government's own admission, the budget will do nothing for unemployment at all. The government agrees there is no hope of a brighter outlook for the jobless in the foreseeable future. If this is their number one priority, then they have already admitted failure and broken their promise to Australia and to Australians. Of course, it is clear that, having attained government by claiming that they care about the unemployed and by claiming that they will continue to provide opportunities for people to retrain for the workplace, that priority has been quickly abandoned. It is just a bit of trickery, really—cruel trickery.

No longer do you hear people on the government side saying that unemployment is the country's most pressing problem. These days they say the most pressing problem is the deficit. Before the election, they portrayed themselves as being compassionate, saying that they would frame their policies to create jobs. After winning government, though, what has happened? They have shed the costume and framed a cruel budget based on false assumptions.

The government has abandoned those who are looking for work and those who are facing redundancy for the deficit—the third lowest deficit in the industrialised world? So much for their care about the needs of people, about the plight of the unemployed. This budget completely abolishes $1.8 billion worth of job training and reskilling programs for those seeking work. It abandons all those who are looking for work, young and old, a decision that will deny 230,000 people the training and the skilling they need in order to get ready for the workplace. The truth is that creating jobs was not a priority in the framing of this budget; it was not even a factor. It has been shuffled a long way down the list of priorities, down as far as it has always been for conservative governments.

The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) said on television the other night that if unemployment does not come down then the government does not deserve to be re‐elected. But it has already demonstrated that it is not willing to formulate a budget designed to bring down unemployment.

This budget will actually make people sick. This budget ruins the quality of health care. There are direct cuts to health care. There are huge cuts in funding to the states, which means that the states will cut health funding. There is also evidence of the first steps in the dismantling of Medicare. Despite the government promising that its policies would not entail cuts to public hospitals, the budget does just that—lopping around $800 million off public hospital funding.

The abolition of the Commonwealth dental care program, which provided basic and emergency dental care to health card and Commonwealth seniors card holders, is a particularly mean and heartless act which will bring greater hardship to low income people and particularly the aged.

The Liberals promised to maintain Medicare in its entirety, but in their first budget the promise has already been betrayed. This budget reduces rebates for certain items and increases the maximum patient payment—signposts on the road to dismantlement of the most popular, most successful and fairest health care system this country has ever had.

But that is nothing too surprising. The Prime Minister has been a lifelong opponent of a fair and a decent health care system, and his squinty‐eyed protestations to the contrary during the election campaign can now be seen for what they were. The coalition also promised to maintain the Medicare levy at 1½ per cent. That promise is broken. The budget contains a lot more broken promises, all of which will mean greater hardship for aged pensioners and other beneficiaries. For example, the coalition had promised to maintain the real value of rent assistance. That promise is broken.

The budget increases the pharmaceutical benefits scheme co‐payment for all health card holders without offering any compensation whatsoever, which effectively cuts the real value of pensions and other benefits. The coalition promised to maintain the real value of pensions and benefits. That promise is broken.

The coalition promised not to force those eligible for the disability support pension onto unemployment or other benefits. That promise is broken. It promised to maintain a lump sum advance system. That promise is broken. It promised to introduce a pension bonus plan. That promise is broken. The list goes on.

But it is easy to expect the Liberals to frame a budget which hits low income people and beneficiaries the hardest—they always do it. This budget, however, also attacks those on middle incomes: the middle Australia the Prime Minister wanted to feel relaxed and comfortable; the middle Australia the Prime Minister claimed had faired badly and deserved extra support. In fact, it is middle Australia who will feel the brunt of this government's ideological, zealous, irrational cost‐cutting.

For families with incomes in the middle range, the small tax cuts offered will be more than countered by a whole raft of increased charges. For example, families will have to pay more for child care; they will have to pay more to give their children a decent education; they will have to pay more to have their elderly parents looked after in a nursing home; and they will have to pay more for hospital and medical care.

Take child care, for example. Those using community‐based child care will have to find an additional $14 a week. That alone is far more than what they will get with the tax cuts. In all, the government is taking $500 million out of child care and it is that amount that parents across the country will have to pay from their own pockets to make up the shortfall.

But the Prime Minister also wants the middle range family to pay for the nursing home care for their ageing parents. They may be asked to find $26,000 to buy them entry into a nursing home—maybe more—and then face the new daily fee of up to $34 a day. How will families on middle incomes afford these extra imposts? For those aged persons living in their own homes and utilising the range of services provided under Labor's home and community care program, higher user‐pay charges will apply. Again, it is their children and their families who will have to foot the bill—and add the increase to $20 per script for prescription drugs.

But while middle Australia has been hit very hard, it is a budget which will bring perhaps the greatest hardship to older Australians. Firstly, they will be hit with the abolition of the dental health program and next by the failure of the government to adjust the deeming rate to reflect lower interest rates attainable by age pensioners on their savings without having to put their money at risk. The budget cuts the real incomes of age pensioners. And changes in superannuation will unfairly deplete the retirement incomes of those people who retire or who are retrenched at 55 years of age.

This budget will also bring hardship because of its failure to support business. The budget abolishes the research and development syndication, despite the coalition praising it before the election, and reduces the tax concession rate for research and development. These broken promises, along with cuts to a range of schemes and programs like Austrade and AusIndustry, will severely retard small to medium enterprises in their pursuit of innovation and excellence. Is this not the very thing this country needs to create employment and turn around our terms of trade?

There are broken promises in almost every area of government administration most of which I have not even time to mention here. For example, the cuts in Aboriginal programs were a vicious, callous and totally unwarranted attack on some of the most vulnerable people in our community. Another example is the $1.4 billion to be paid by university students in payments and repayments of their course fees. Another broken promise.

Those who remember the Prime Minister when he was the former Liberal Treasurer do not find the broken promises surprising. Nothing has changed in the Prime Minister's head, but he has employed, I admit, better make‐over people. Other broken promises include: cuts to the environment, roads—$622 million—tourism, trade, the ABC, education, the arts, foreign aid, and on it goes.

The Prime Minister made a big play in the lead‐up to the election about promising Australians a comfortable and a relaxed nation. That promise is broken. This budget will eventually make a lot of people in Australia very uncomfortable and very anxious while at the same time it will send this country intellectually to sleep.

This budget makes almost every sector of the Australian community pay more for the services they currently enjoy while completely abolishing other important services, typically those services which assist those most in need. The focus of the attack on those most in need was, however, predictable. Conservative governments compulsively attack those in need the hardest.

But what was even surprising to me, and not predictable, was the extent to which middle Australia will be made to pay for this budget. And pay they will, for everything from child care, to health care, to education for their children and nursing home care for their ageing parents. But the budget's big failure is a failure to steer the country, a failure to lead. This is the failure which follows inevitably from the failure of vision. This government has no vision for this country. It has no clear view of where it wants to go. This much we know from the budget. This is a budget steering us nowhere in particular. It is a dead hand—as Kim Beazley has said—on the national tiller.

Conservative governments do not lead. Instead, they hand over government to a particular stream of the bureaucracy, to the public servants from Treasury and Finance, who are just the captives of the financial markets. They do not make policy to drive Australia forward; they let their departments in Canberra shuffle the cards. They do not roll up their sleeves and work at the engine of government; they wash their hands of the responsibility of government. They put the country to sleep.

In that respect, this budget returns Australia to the sleepwalking days of the 1950s and 1960s, and even the late 1970s—the era when opportunity passed this country by, the era when our national economic infrastructure developed the great structural faults which Labor has, for the last 13 years, sought to mend. It was the era of the big, irresponsible conservative yawn. True to form, this is a budget which will send Australia to sleep. It is a budget devoid of vision and it is based on false assumptions. It is a product of ideological zealotry, of a frenzy of cost cutting for the wrong reasons, of a failure to reason and of a complete absence of compassion. It is a budget without the spine of commonsense evident in all sensible and responsible offerings. It is a budget that will take this country nowhere.And it is a budget that will cause great hardship for most in our community—and the greatest hardship will have to be borne by those with the greatest need.

The budget slashes billions of dollars out of government programs—and those billions of dollars are going to have to be found by ordinary working Australians. It is a complete fabrication for the government to argue that the hardship they are inflicting upon Australians with this budget is a harsh but necessary medicine. It is a medicine forced down the throat of a healthy economy, a cure for a non‐existent illness.

The real reason is simply ideological zealotry. They do not see a role for government in assisting people in our community who are in need. They do not see a role for leadership. They believe in a crass sort of individualism which, in their thinking, overrides any sense of collective responsibility for the country and the community we are building. They think that, if people are in need of government assistance, they have not worked hard enough. They submit to the fundamentally flawed idea that somebody's failure to get a job, or hold a job, is that person's own fault. You look at the budget papers and you think, `What is the matter with this word "unemployment"?' The old word processor got a bit of a blip, didn't it? You hardly see a mention of it anywhere.

This Liberal government also commits itself to the fundamentally stupid idea that, if somebody gets sick, then it is their responsibility to be able to pay for the medical treatment they need. If they or their kids cannot afford to go to the dentist or to the doctor or to have an education, the government's view—according to this budget—is that they therefore do not deserve any of these services. There are three members of the opposition here—I mean the government. I cannot get used to it, can I?

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be the case for a while, too.

—I remember the times before Medicare, when aged people, vulnerable people, sat in doctors' surgeries from nine o'clock to five or six o'clock at night and were then told to come back again. This is the era that you are going to bring us back to. Or perhaps the message of this budget is that people who cannot afford dental care should resort to the practice of 50 years ago and get all their teeth pulled out in order to avoid the cost of dental care altogether.

BREAK.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit sensitive to that, are you? The conservatives have always been big on whips and punishments. The government's ideological position leaves no room for the idea of collective responsibility, for fairness or equality of opportunity. They subordinate those principles and guiding thoughts to the notions of individual rights and user pays, regardless of the capacity to pay. Just like any plan with concocted wrong reasons, it will fail. This budget was framed on debt and deficit and that has clearly made the proposition unworkable. It is simply not true. This is a government that framed the budget and said that higher productivity will lead to higher employment. Wrong. This is a government that says downsizing will lead to more productivity. Wrong. This is a government that links interest rates to surpluses. Wrong.

BREAK.PARA: They are the four frameworks, the four parameters, on which you have based this budget. Can you not see that, if you base it on the wrong reasons, then the fundamentals in terms of the processes and the outcomes that you deliver are going to be wrong?This Howard‐Costello budget will fail all Australians. So much for a government elected on the slogan, `For all of us.'

There are on the government side perhaps 35 new members and probably 30 of them—at least 20 of them—are in for the short stay in parliament. They are in for the short stay in parliament because when you come new to this place it is a bit of a culture shock for all of us. But they have been manipulated. Their lack of experience in the place has seen them agree to a budget that is going to harm many people in their constituencies, and when it comes to September 1997 everyone in their electorates will know. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —What does this national coalition budget mean to Australians in this great nation of ours? Could it be a glimmer of hope to some? Yes, I think so. Could it be the green light for small business that will instil economic confidence? Once again I think so.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many initiatives in this budget. The most important is the reaction of the financial markets to reduce interest rates as a result of the sound policy decisions of this government for reducing the massive debt left by the opposition. This has had a major effect on home owners and small business people who have suffered for far too long.

Yet there is more to come, a lot more. When the coalition's industrial relations reform passes the Senate it will rectify a number of the anomalies that have been holding small business back. They will then be able to start employing people and creating real jobs. We will also be encouraging small business to take on more apprentices and trainees instead of running costly training programs in basket making, for instance, only to see those involved return to the unemployment queues.

The reduction of the provisional tax uplift factor will provide a great boost to the small business sector, as will the allowance to claim an exemption from capital gains tax up to $500,000 on the sale of a business when proceeds are used for retirement. The small business task force investigation will also provide a lot of the answers the business community is asking for, such as a reduction in bureaucratic red tape and paperwork.

I have a vision for the electorate of Capricornia. I have set goals that I expect to achieve. Some may say that I will never get the money from government to put major infrastructure into my electorate, such as extending the dam wall at Mount Morgan and building a dam in the Dawson Valley. And the many other projects that will follow will reduce unemployment in my area.

However, I am used to working with knockers, people who focus on the tall poppy syndrome and only want to knock one's tireless efforts. There are those who knock the many initiatives in this budget that have been carefully planned for the people. I say to those people that the new Austrade office will give producers of any product the ability to directly trade overseas from my electorate of Capricornia; there is the $1 million for accommodation at Shoalwater Bay for the military; and there is the 6.25 per cent increase to local government in untied financial assistance and road funding grants. I am proud to say I had great pleasure in championing these projects for my electorate.

BREAK.PARA: The increased funding to local government in Queensland became a very real need to me as I was a councillor on the Belyando Shire Council in Capricornia. My council colleagues, including the mayor of the Belyando Shire Council, Councillor Jim Turner, Councillor Margaret Henn, Councillors Mary and Dale Langford and Councillor Arthur Plate—just to name a few—always instilled in me the need to fight for increased funding for local shires.

This was followed up by reams of paperwork and literature passed on to me by the chief executive officer of the Belyando Shire Council, Mr Alan Lambert. This paperwork was generated in an effort to receive the result that the executive director of the Queensland Local Government Association, Mr Greg Hallam, called for when he lobbied all candidates prior to the 2 March election.

Another institution in Capricornia also received funding. I hate to mention it, really, because I know it really sticks in the throat of the member for Hotham (Mr Crean). I mean that it sticks in his throat, for he is still trying to get his foot out of his mouth after his statements, made to the media while visiting my electorate, regarding the funding shortfall to the Central Queensland University. To his surprise, it just so happens that the university received a nine per cent increase in its funding over the next three years, and not a cut. The vice‐chancellor and the acting president of the student union have both come out saying they are pleased with the budget outcomes.

Back to the knockers. I consider myself a rather humble sort of man. I say this with great passion: apart from my Christian views on life, my good wife, Leica, and those close to me in my family, nothing else is as important to me as the people of Capricornia. With this thick hide and these broad shoulders I will soldier on to provide a result to my employers at home—the residents of Capricornia.

No matter where you go, you cannot please everyone. I understand this. More to the point, people do not mind change as long as it is not to them. So, if changes to social security hurt some, or certain jobs are lost because funding has run out, I say, `Don't despair, there will be other opportunities out there for you.' To this end, I will continue to make representations to this government to continue to receive money for projects that will give full‐time jobs, not just two‐ to three‐month training programs that lift your hopes and then throw you back on the unemployment queues.

With this coalition budget, I see new initiatives that will cause my electorate of Capricornia to prosper and grow. It is a shame the other side of the House will not look ahead to see the big picture. It is very clear to me that until politicians from both sides of the fence scrum together and put forward constructive criticism that is to the benefit of this great nation we will continue to have people miss out, owing to ego‐driven individuals who are not prepared to wear a little humble pie for the good of this country.

After my previous statement, it would be remiss of me not to point out an area that I will continue to lobby the Minister for Health and Family Services (Mr Wooldridge) on. That is operational subsidies to community based child‐care centres. I am concerned that some of these centres in my electorate will suffer as a consequence of this decision. Some of these centres are in drought‐stricken areas where the money is tight. There are a number of single mothers who have to go out to work to make ends meet.

I take on board the fact that these cuts only bring all the centres into line with the privately‐owned centres, which is fair to all. So, at this stage, until the smoke clears and we can see exactly what will be the end result of this initiative, I will continue to monitor the funding cuts.

Another issue I will be taking up, with the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), is the 500 per cent increase in the environment management charge, which, because it was introduced to be effective immediately, will hurt a number of tourist operators in my electorate and the adjoining electorates of Wide Bay, Hinkler, Dawson, Herbert and Leichhardt. I strongly support my coalition colleagues in opposing this increase as it stands. Together, I am sure we will convince the minister to reconsider the implications that this increase will have for our tourism industry. While it is fair enough to charge tourists for the costs of maintaining the reef and the local environment, it is not fair to impose the charge on the local operators—which is exactly what this does—as they cannot pass the increased charge on to pre‐booked tourists.

While I am on the subject of the environmental management charge increase, I was astounded today to be handed a press release issued by the ex‐Speaker of the House, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), which claimed the coalition members affected by this increase had voted against a motion to debate it. This grubby attempt by the member for Cunningham to politicise the amicable negotiation efforts of the south‐east Queensland members in this important matter is nothing more than a blatant lie. It is a typical political stunt by the opposition to pull on a debate ahead of its time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will withdraw that statement.
—Okay, I will withdraw that statement, but—
—Just a moment. You withdraw the statement and you do not refer to members of the House by their—
—The member for Cunningham.
—Yes, the member for Cunningham, and you withdraw the implication that he is a liar.
—Okay, fair enough, I withdraw. But that does not change the fact that the problem was there and his statements were not fair.

BREAK.PARA: On another sensitive subject, I heard the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission kick up a stink over shortfalls to funding to its previously exaggerated budget. I have seen Aboriginal people miss out on the necessities of life such as housing, health care and education owing to the wealthy administration of ATSIC and to its commissioners not passing the money down the line to the people who really need it. Until the commission proves there are no inequities in its system and stands accountable to the public, then a cut to ATSIC is warranted.

In relation to ATSIC and its rules for one and not another, let me raise the issue of ATSIC's election of office bearers. ATSIC holds secret ballots and conducts non‐compulsory voting to elect its representatives. This is completely opposite to the Australian parliamentary system of electing representatives. ATSIC calls for equality and reconciliation, yet it is not prepared to adopt a democratic and accountable system for its people.

There are many people in this country whose ancestors were sent here in chains for offences that today we regard as petty. They did not have a choice but were taken from their families and dumped in a strange land across the seas, thousands of miles from their homes. Would it be unfair to say then that they have equal claims? Two hundred years later, would it not be fair for their ancestors to expect the Australian taxpayer to keep them in the same way as the Aborigines? I do not think any other Australian would expect that either.

In relation to ATSIC and its rules for one and not another, I must say on behalf of all those good black and white Australians out there that, while there are two sets of rules for the people of this great nation, the country will continue to be divided.

I have heard some individuals complain about the changes to HECS, but for every one who has complained I have heard four others who say it is about time the system was made fair and equitable. To explain this, an example is called for. I have a friend called Scott who has a truck courier business that operates from Rockhampton throughout the central Queensland area.

This is a good example. To get his start in life, Scott chose to buy a truck. He paid up front. I think he even had to borrow the money from a lending institution. For Scott, it was an up‐front investment fee of say $60,000. What would he expect to net after mechanical expenses and fuel running costs to the truck? Maybe $55,000 a year income.

Now let us look at the HECS scheme previous to the proposed changes. Students could study at university, complete a course—or should I say, purchase an investment or asset from the Commonwealth—at approximately $2,500 a year and not pay it back until they were employed and/or earning an income of $28,500 a year.

With this in mind, it is not hard to argue the case for change. It is a person's decision to purchase the asset in relation to the income they wish to make. I will explain. A degree in teaching may give an annual return of say $35,000 to $40,000 a year, therefore a relatively low HECS fee should be considered. A student wishing to purchase an asset that has the capacity to earn say $200,000 to $300,000 a year should have to pay more for his or her investment or asset.

The repayments for that asset are worked out on a percentage of their income after they begin to earn $20,000 per annum and then not until they have the capacity to pay it back, which means it could be some time before they start work—many students I know shoot off overseas for a well‐deserved break before getting into full‐time employment. They are not even compelled to start making payments until they have a job. Under these circumstances, this is a fair initiative.

I say to one and all the cuts to every area had to come. We cannot afford to continue to throw money at everything that moves. We have to tighten our belts a little or the children—yes, our future generations—will be left with a country, or more to the fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, they will be left with nothing for we will have written cheques that our taxpayers cannot afford to pay. It is time to put our best foot forward and not take a selfish outlook on life and give this country the future of love and prosperity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to take part in the appropriations and speak on the budget. I support the amendment moved by the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). This is Jobless Johnny's first budget and it is a very disappointing budget. There is no growth, no jobs and no job certainty. When one discusses the appropriation bill it is always important and relevant to look at some of the macro-economic framework that the budget is placed in. When you look at the macro-economic framework you see that things are not looking good so far as growth in the economy is concerned, so far as jobs and job certainty and security are concerned and so far as unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment, is concerned.

BREAK.PARA: I will not actually start with the budget paper. I will start with a very important part of members' reading in this place and that is the 1996 annual report of the Reserve Bank which the former Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser, signed off on 6 August. It is a nice prelude to the budget on 20 August and at page 11 the board refers to the labour market and says as follows:

Employment growth was broadly in line with the path of economic activity but the within-year movements were quite variable and their interpretation was complicated by uncertainties relating to the data. Over the year, employment rose by 1.0 per cent compared with 4¾ per cent during the previous year. The slowing was evident among both part-time and full‐time workers but was more pronounced among full-time workers. Despite the slower growth in l995‐96, employment has increased by around 10 per cent or over 750,000 since the trough of the recession in mid 1991. Over the past 18 months the slowing in employment has been more pronounced than the slowing in economic growth.
So the scene for the budget on 20 August as signed off by the Governor of the Reserve Bank is a slowing in employment and a slowing in economic growth.
When you move on in the board's report to pages 12 and 13, the board has this to say:

The unemployment rate was largely unchanged over the year at around 8½ per cent. Long-term unemployment continued to fall in 1995-96 with the unemployment for those out of work for more than a year falling to 2¼ per cent of the total labour force. This is still higher than for much of the 1980s but well down on the peak of the above 4 per cent recorded in mid 1993. The concentration of unemployment among certain groups in the community suggests that, while lasting reductions in unemployment require sustained growth and economic activity, combined with restraints in labour costs, there is also a role for training and other programs targeted at groups figuring prominently among the unemployed.

What is the board saying here? The board is handcuffing itself, as the previous government did with the Working Nation white paper, to the notion of the need for economic growth to create employment and the need for programs aimed directly at unemployed, particularly long-term unemployed. I repeat what the board had to say, `. . . there is also a role for training and other programs targeted at groups figuring prominently among the unemployed'. That is why it is so distressing to see a budget which has no economic growth, therefore no prospects for employment growth, no prospects for reduction in long-term unemployment and, at the same time, a massive reduction in the expenditure outlaid for those programs which are aimed at trying to give the long-term unemployed, in particular, a chance at employment.

When you turn to the budget itself, some 14 days after the Governor of the Reserve Bank signed off the bank's 1996 report, if I refer the committee to Budget Paper No. 1, it is interesting to see how through the macro‐economic forecasts and statements in Budget Paper No. 1, you get a very clear understanding of the notion of no jobs, no growth, higher unemployment and higher long‐term unemployment. In some other matters I will refer to subsequently, I think that we will see that these forecasts are now a bit tenuous and in some respects are optimistic.

At table 6 at page 1‐20 of Budget Paper No. 1 we find the forecasts for growth or real GDP. The forecast for 1996‐97 is 3½ per cent; for 1997‐98, 3¼ per cent; for 1998‐99, 3½ per cent; and for 1999‐2000, 3½ per cent. All are forecast below four per cent, which is that percentage of economic growth generally regarded as the percentage you need to make some inroads into unemployment. Anything less than four per cent is basically just picking up those newer entrants to the labour market. Page 2‐3 states:
Economic growth is expected to continue at a firm and sustainable pace in 1996‐97 with GDP forecast to rise by 3½ per cent.

There are two things here: again, confirmation that we are looking at modest proportions of economic growth, but also there is a bit of an illusion here—I frankly do not regard 3½ per cent of growth as firm and sustainable or, as it is referred to subsequently in the papers, as `a forecast for strong growth'. It is simply growth in the economy that is barely enough to take care of those newer entrants to the labour market.
Moving on, under the heading `Employment and Unemployment' at 2‐15 of Budget Paper No. 1, we find the budget paper saying:

Despite continued fairly rapid growth in year average terms, employment growth eased significantly through the course of 1995‐96, increasing by around one per cent in the year to the June quarter 1996 compared with 4.8 per cent in the previous year.
At page 2‐20:
Australia's economic outlook is for another year of strong growth.
I do not regard 3½ per cent as strong growth. And the final comment in the macro-economic section of Budget Paper No. 1, again under `Employment and Unemployment':

With continued non‐farm GDP growth and an expected deceleration in real wage growth, employment growth should accelerate through 1996‐97. However, a slowing in employment growth in year average terms is likely given the weak outcomes in the second half of 1995‐96. The current level of job vacancies and the expectations reported in business surveys, support a short‐term outlook of modest employment growth. Increasing employment opportunities and higher real wages through the course of 1996‐97, should encourage people to re‐enter or enter the work force, resulting in modest rises in the participation rate. With the labour force expected to grow solidly through 1996‐97, the unemployment rate is expected to decline only gradually to around 8¼ per cent in the June quarter 1997 compared with 8.6 per cent in the June quarter 1996.

On the budget paper's assessment, which I will argue is now in a sense an optimistic assessment as far as employment and unemployment is concerned, and a massively optimistic assessment so far as defining 3½ per cent growth as strong, the key element arising out of this budget is no jobs, no growth, no job certainty. Jobless Johnny has really set himself to his nickname with this particular budget.
But shortly after the budget we find in the Australian on Friday, 6 September the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, saying:

Long‐term jobless may rise with reforms. The federal government's radical redesign of labour market assistance might not reduce the number of long‐term unemployed, Minister Vanstone conceded yesterday. Senator Vanstone said it was, `theoretically possible that long‐term unemployment would rise.'

For `theoretically possible', read `absolutely sure and certain' because what have we seen since budget day? What we have seen since budget day is the unemployment figures for August 1996 going above and beyond any of the forecasts or expectations that we find in the budget so far as unemployment is concerned with the monthly rate for August 1996 at 8.8 per cent.
The Banker's Trust, in its commentary on the monthly unemployment figures for August had this to say:
Our quick conclusion is that the labour market is still just muddling along.
The member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), I know, would be interested in this quote.

The unemployment rate for males rose from 8.5 per cent to 9.1 per cent, its highest level since last October. The female unemployment rate was steady at 8.4 per cent. Almost all of the rise in unemployment in the month was accounted for by males. Who'd be a bloke?
And they conclude their comment by saying:
The labour market is simply stagnating, getting neither better nor worse.
Again, I think that is optimistic, given what we have seen in the last couple of days in so far as a couple of surveys and forecasts are concerned.

There is one point I would like to focus on for a moment. That is the notion of the need for economic growth to create employment, but also the need for governments and society to take special steps or measures to do their best to give unemployed people—in particular, long‐term unemployed people—the chance of getting back into employment. It is the notion picked up in the Reserve Bank's report which I have referred to, and it was the intellectual and policy basis of the previous government's Working Nation report.

The shorthand version of that policy approach is simply `growth plus'. In other words, you need economic growth, but you have got to take special steps or extra measures to make sure that the long‐term unemployed in particular get a chance of employment. And what have we seen in this budget? On the one hand, no growth, no jobs, no job certainty. And on the other hand, a massive slashing of the programs and the funds devoted to those special measures or extra steps.

At the same time, if it was not enough for these very modest growth proportions or projections to be subscribed to by the government, in areas where we know we have had considerable success over the last decade in improving economic growth and jobs—namely, our export performance and Australian industry's performance—we also see, systematically through the budget papers, industry assistance, incentive or support programs and trade or export enhancement or incentive programs either abolished in breach of election promises or massively slashed.

If you are interested in building ships and exporting them, the bounty is gone. If you are interested in being a small or medium size company that exports, the EMDG scheme has been gutted effectively and a cap of $150 million put on it, cutting EMDG expenditure by $426 million over a four‐year period in breach of an election commitment. That commitment was that funds to EMDG and Austrade would be cut by $58.3 million over a three‐year period. And my reference is just to the EMDG scheme. When you look at what is occurring in Austrade you effectively have $90 million cut out of appropriations for this financial year.

It is in that context that we saw the release yesterday by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Westpac Bank of their September quarterly survey of industrial trends in manufactures in Australia. In the course of the materials released by the ACCI and Westpac yesterday we find Bill Evans, the General Manager, Economics, for Westpac commenting:

Given that the budget was aimed at restoring business confidence and its associated forecast predicted a very healthy 14 per cent increase in business investments, the results of the survey, in showing that manufacturing activity continued to ease, will be disappointing for the government.

In other words, the 3½ per cent maximum growth which is in the budget papers is predicated on a 14 per cent increase in business investment. And, a short time after the budget, the ACCI and Westpac are saying that you will not necessarily get that private investment. So, in addition to all the other things that are going on that I have referred to, you are not necessarily going to get the private investment which is also required to meet the very modest growth projections that we see in the budget. Mr Evans continued:

Another worrying sign relates to employment. The March and June surveys reflected an economy where employment growth was negligible. Hopes for a stronger employment performance in the September quarter are not supported by this survey. Expectations for the December quarter offer little hope of any significant improvement in employment conditions.
In other words, don't expect any great increase in employment and, on the other hand, what will you also get? You will get an increase in unemployment.
In the highlights by the ACCI and Westpac, there is a specific reference to unemployment. It says:

Labour shedding continued in the September quarter with a net balance of minus 24 per cent versus minus 23 per cent previously. A further decline in numbers employed is expected in the December quarter with a net balance of minus 19 per cent. The decline in overtime work is expected to continue in the next three months
The survey shows, not an increase in employment, but a decrease in employment and a consequent increase in unemployment.
The summary of the survey of industrial trends released at the same time by the ACCI and Westpac says:

Manufacturing activity continued to ease with actual outcomes in the September quarter 1996 broadly similar to those reported in the previous three quarters. New orders, output, employment and overtime work all declined, in most instances marginally more quickly than in the previous quarter.

So, where is the trend line going? Down. Employment is going down. Orders are going down. Investment is going down. The trend line in unemployment is up. Jobless Johnny: no jobs, no growth and no support for the long‐term unemployed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—As a point of order, I would ask the honourable member to withdraw that and to refer to the members of the House by their titles.
—The budget of the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) will have the effect of increasing joblessness in Australia.
—Thank you.
—The survey goes on to say:

BREAK.PARA: Capacity utilisation remained at low levels. Increases in new orders and output are again predicted for the next quarters with expectations for new orders strongest in the lead‐up to Christmas.

And you can look at the tables that are attached to the survey, under the headings `Employment: Labour shedding continues unabated' and `Overtime declining'. And I will not take any further time on that particular survey.

Then you can look at the MTIA's budget assessment. The MTIA in its input special budget production has a very nice table which makes these points quite illustratively: `The outcomes and forecasts, main economic forecasts from the 1996‐97 budget'. The MTIA, in its formal budget response, refers to risks and challenges, and makes the very obvious comment: `four per cent plus growth must be our goal'. But for the forecasts and the statistics which the MTIA regard as being significant:
GDP—outcome 1995‐96 year average, 4.1; forecast 1996‐96, 3.5—
growth is down.
Exports of goods and services—1995‐96 year average, 4.3; forecast, 8
‐ exports are down.
Imports of goods and services—year average 1995‐96, 5.6; forecast, 1996‐96 year average, 11
imports are up.
Unemployment rate, 8.5 year average 1995‐96; forecast, 8.5

last month, we saw 8.8 and all the evidence from the surveys that I have referred to are for that to increase. And we saw in the Australian today a summary of those reports under the heading `Jobless forecast fuels fears of economic slowdown'. The article stated:
Fresh evidence that unemployment could soon reach 9 per cent and the prospect of further job losses in manufacturing have fuelled fears of a budget induced economic slowdown.
That is obviously the case, given the measures contained in the budget. The article continues:
As the worst long‐term jobless figures in seven months were released
yesterday. . .
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry found manufacturers expected labour‐shedding to continue. . .
Westpac's general manager, economics, Mr Bill Evans, said there was "a chance" that unemployment could hit 9 per cent by the end of the year. . .

The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported that the number of long‐term unemployed . . . rose to 229,300 in August. It was the third monthly increase in a row and the highest figure since January. Senior Treasury officials played down hopes of a rapid improvement in employment from the Government's labour market reforms.

And, of course, the other thing that we are regaled with in the budget is the Budget Paper's waxing lyrical about all these problems which will be solved by the government's workplace reform bill. All you have got to do is force the wages down, give the workers low‐paid jobs, and that will solve all the problems of the world. So I was very pleased to see that Professor Gregory was reported in the Financial Review today challenging this very simplistic notion that those on the other side always love to handcuff themselves to—namely, that we will solve all the problems of the world by just pushing down the workers' wages.
The Financial Review article, which is headlined `Gregory challenges Government push on labour flexibility', says:
. . . Professor Bob Gregory has issued a sweeping new challenge to Federal Government claims that greater labour market flexibility will significantly reduce unemployment in Australia.
Professor Gregory argues. . . that Government moves toward creating a more US‐style labour market will reduce the wages of low‐paid workers.
`The restoration of full employment will lie in a direction other than reducing the wages of the low paid,' he says.
The article continues:

Noting the Government's claim that its planned individual employment contracts will not worsen employment terms and conditions, Professor Gregory says: `Is it possible to reduce unemployment and produce jobs by creating greater labour market flexibility, but ensure that this flexibility does not extend to reducing wages and conditions?'

So Professor Gregory scotches the simplistic notion that coalition members have always trotted out in this place that all one has to do is crush the workers' wages and the problems of the world will be solved. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to address the Main Committee on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). It is quite interesting listening to the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), who gave us a bit of an economics lesson today. But what is quite extraordinary is that some time ago he worked for the former Prime Minister in the Treasurer's department. He quoted so many figures of economic growth, but debt level was not mentioned once. He did not reveal that we had the highest interest rates under the previous Labor government and somehow he tried to link unemployment rates with the new incoming government. It was quite interesting that he did not once speak of the debt levels that he left this country with.

SPEECH.PARA: It was extraordinary that under the previous government we had high economic growth but we have also had high levels of unemployment. I might put to you that the reason that people are not employing—and every person that I speak to will not employ people—is that we need to sort out the industrial relations area. Until that legislation goes through that is the disincentive, not the economics figures and statistics that you quoted.

The first budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) is based on fair and responsible economic management. It is an accumulation of many hours of hard work, and many industry, business and community groups around Australia, and in particular in my electorate of Petrie, have shown their appreciation by applauding the budget. The appropriation bills are Australia's litmus test for the next three years. From the federal election six months ago, this government, the first coalition government in 13 years, has a mandate to return this country to strong economic management. This government has taken the responsibility to bring the $10 billion deficit back to level terms in three years, to throw out the ALP's unfair dismissal laws, to privatise one‐third of Telstra, to get small business back working and to provide for the heart and soul of this country, which is families.

This government has a mandate because under Labor interest rates were at record high levels, unemployment reached levels not seen since the Great Depression and national youth unemployment soared to well over 20 per cent.

As a new member of the House of Representatives representing the seat of Petrie in the northern suburbs of Brisbane, I eagerly awaited the first coalition budget in 13 years. There was a lot of pre‐budget speculation around. There were the opposition calls of a horror budget and scaremongering among many groups in the community. My electorate office was ready for that Wednesday following the budget, and were we inundated with budget negativity? No, no, no. My constituents instead were calling me bitterly complaining about the riots at Parliament House and disgusted at the burning of the symbol of Australia, our flag: an episode which I would like all members in this particular chamber to thoroughly condemn. People calling my office were more concerned about the welfare of myself and my staff and offered their assistance, and I thank all those people who contacted my office for their consideration and thoughts.

The Petrie electorate includes people from all walks of life: small business, schools, older residents, the fishing industry and local government. Each stands to gain from this budget. As I talk to people in the electorate, I feel that this is a budget for families, for young people in our community, a budget for small business. In fact, it is a tremendous boost to get this country working again.

Families are the life and soul of our community. It is the family unit, no matter what shape or size, that is the cornerstone of society. It is families who have found it so incredibly tough over the last 13 years. Double figure unemployment rates, high youth unemployment and high interest rates have left families wondering where the next dollar is going to come from. There are many families out there who are just living from week to week with the bare minimum in their shopping trolleys. This government will provide assistance through family tax initiatives and by providing financial incentives to low and middle income families who invest in private health insurance.

This government came into power on the platform of giving hope, of giving respite to families who have struggled particularly hard over the last five years. In the government's first budget, we have delivered. As promised, Medicare has been retained in its entirety and the operational subsidy for family day care centres has been retained, as has child‐care assistance and the child‐care cash rebate. The government has provided a fair and responsible budget; a budget which will help the hip‐pocket of the people of Australia and will give confidence to the marketplace and encourage consumer spending and self‐esteem.

From my electorate's perspective, one of the most pleasing aspects of the budget has been its flow‐on effects for young people. The Howard government believes young people have for far too long been neglected, with sky‐rocketing unemployment, spiralling suicide rates, and a lack of hope and inspiration. This cannot continue. Our young people, next year's generation, need hope and inspiration, and our budget delivers. Working Nation has failed a lot of those young people and the long‐term unemployed. For too long these people have been going through the revolving door of endless labour market training programs before returning to the unemployment lines. Real jobs did not eventuate, and many of these people lost hope. Confidence in the system plummeted.

In workplace reforms, the move towards a quality apprenticeship system for young people has been very well received in the community. Many people can remember the days when apprenticeships led to real jobs. You cannot beat the experience gained from working on the job, and skill based training lays the foundation for a quality system. The apprenticeship system that we have instigated reflects the modern labour market and the needs of business and industry; provides world‐class training in skills that business and industry require; gives employers a key role in determining the kinds of skills and training required; and also makes training arrangements simpler and far more flexible.

The apprenticeship system put forward by this government is a step towards growth and employment options. The changes proposed in this government's industrial relations mandate will allow for flexible training arrangements. It gives more options and opportunities through small and medium sized businesses, so important to the economic vitality of the Petrie electorate. These changes, importantly, will allow businessmen in my electorate—such as cabinet‐makers, fibreglass moulders, mechanics, printers, typesetters and electricians—to expand their businesses, using the talent and skills of the young as apprentices in an affordable and well‐managed system. The apprenticeship scheme proposed by this government needs to be cultivated and supported, and can in time bring tremendous benefits to this country.

I also wish to support the government's move to curb the high levels of youth homelessness. Organisations such as the Society of St Vincent de Paul, Lifeline, the Smith Family, City Missions, the Salvation Army and those individuals who spend their life comforting those on the street must be applauded. These people have hearts of gold and high levels of determination and dedication, and most of them work in a voluntary capacity in very trying circumstances. The growth of homelessness in our communities is debilitating and does nothing for the self‐esteem of families or communities.

In a recent edition of the Queensland Courier‐Mail, I was saddened to read that the Council to Homeless Persons has warned that Queensland's rate of homelessness was `nearly twice the national average'. The article reported that it had been estimated that there were some 61,000 homeless people in Australia, of which homeless families make up 13 per cent. Community groups are taking more and more responsibility each and every day, and people are crying out for comfort, support and someone to talk to. It has been estimated that there are over 20,000 homeless young people aged between 12 and 18. This figure is a very sad indictment of our society, and something needs to be done.

The youth homelessness pilot program shows the government's commitment to this important area of society. With an $8 million package over three years, it will focus on family relations. The strategy is based on improving the existing supports available and reviewing the ways that information is transferred from community groups to income support agencies. Early intervention and family reconciliation are other areas which are being supported. The fact that the program is voluntary is also important.

Similarly, youth suicide is an issue that has touched many families. Australia's suicide rate is one of the highest in the world and this government is prepared to take a stand here. Research and early intervention measures are needed. Counselling services are in great demand and the national youth suicide strategy will be welcomed in many communities, including those in my electorate.

While on the topic of young people in our society, I attended a function recently at Deception Bay High School, where the principal, Mr Jim Stephens, was so proud of the achievements, academically, socially and culturally, of his students. Furthermore, Redcliffe State High School deserves special mention with their recent result in the Queensland Rock Eisteddfod, where they finished second—a great result for the determination and dedication of students, teachers and parents. Last Saturday, I was delighted to join the principal of that school, Mr Barry Ferris, in opening up their new performing arts complex, where the Commonwealth invested substantial funding. This government continues to support schools and education in such a way to further improve the opportunities that are available.

This budget will provide further incentives for students through educational and training schemes. Over the next four years, Australia's schools will receive $14 billion in funding from the federal government. We are preparing our young people for future employment. In fact, just recently the Australian Secondary School Principals' President, Duncan Stalker, has applauded the fact that schools are to be given direct access to funding to support an increased emphasis on vocational education for the nation's secondary schools. He said:

At long last there is recognition that vocational education is important to secondary schools and has a crucial role in the secondary curriculum. The challenge facing secondary schools is to design and implement vocational courses that are equally valued along with other school programs by students and parents.

The Petrie electorate has welcomed this government's commitment to the job placement, employment and training program. JPET aims to assist young people to establish a stable lifestyle, resolve family conflicts, attain life skills, return to education and prepare for entry to and continuing participation in the work force. I commend the funding of $11 million per year over the next two years which has been set aside for this program. We just cannot forget our young. This government has a rock solid commitment to young people in the Petrie electorate and throughout Australia.

A key area in getting this country back working again is small business. The Attorney‐General only this week released provisional bankruptcy statistics, and it is a disgraceful legacy from the Labor administration. There were over 17,000 bankruptcies for 1995‐96 and in my state of Queensland, as the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) would know, there was a rise of nearly 40 per cent for the financial year. The previous government failed to deliver real industrial relations reform and the current account went out of control, forcing up this country's national debt.

I have spoken previously of the sad sight in my electorate of the growing number of small businesses shutting their doors over the last few years. Vacant shopfronts have become a far too familiar sight in too many suburbs, in community shopping villages and even in the central shopping malls. Capital gains tax initiatives introduced by this budget have been very well received in my electorate and the capital gains rollover relief will, in time, have a very positive benefit for many small businesses. They have the opportunity to expand and to create more jobs. Generous tax treatment for employee share schemes will provide a sense of ownership in our big businesses and encourage participation from within. The government has made a commitment to ensure that a lack of financial operations does not constrain growth and development of small business.

Business leaders representing prominent Australian organisations recently met in Canberra and they have given full support to these budget measures. They called on the minor parties in the Senate to pass the workplace reforms and, as National Farmers Federation President Donald McGauchie said, `We expect the passage of the bill to produce conditions for increased employment and higher wages.' Business will be given a choice in managing their work force and enterprise agreements negotiated under a dual system will provide business with much more flexibility than they presently have with a rigid awards system.

The key area on the mind of every small business person in my electorate is the unfair dismissal scheme. This is an ALP legacy that will stick to the opposition for many years to come. The present unfair dismissal laws are a noose around the head of many small businesses who struggle from week to week. I am talking about the family corner store, the florist, the baker, the butcher, the coffee shop owners and the restaurants—each and every one has grave concerns about these unfair dismissal laws and they are crying out for help.

What has happened is that the move towards casual work has been the death of many full‐time jobs. In some industries, where there have been large turnovers of staff, employers have become very careful with their placements. A coffee shop owner in my electorate recently told me that he no longer employs full‐time employees, preferring instead part‐time and casual workers. This government intends to amend this legislation for benefits across the whole country.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a further measure which is targeted towards jobs—real jobs—for the benefit of our community. This government recognises the needs of the unemployed, particularly those in the 50 to 60 age group. Many of these people find it terribly difficult to re‐enter the work force, through lack of skills or limited opportunities. Whether their predicament is brought about by retrenchment, economic circumstance or family situation—male or female—it is important that the needs of these people be further examined.

On the subject of industry, the fishing industry is a valuable asset to the electorate of Petrie. I represented the interests of the constituents with fishing enterprises recently, to save the diesel fuel rebate scheme from abolishment. I am pleased that the diesel fuel rebate scheme has remained intact. This is of particular significance and will achieve economic sustainability throughout the whole fishing industry. Not enough emphasis is placed on the fishing industry. At the moment, many in the industry who harvest prawns are in a state of decline due to poor climatic conditions. I look forward to working with local and state fishing organisations, processors and consumers, to work towards a more productive sector.

I had the pleasure in Brisbane recently, on behalf of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), of launching the new strategic plan for the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation—a corporation which has been doing commendable work in managing fisheries research and development programs. Research by the Southern Fisheries Centre, coordinated by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries at Deception Bay, has received funding from the government for its projects, particularly in the prawn trawl fisheries. It is budgeted that the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation will invest $13.5 million in 200 new and continuing projects, highlighting the government's commitment to this important resource sector.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the higher education sector is of interest to my constituents. I believe the move by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to announce budget initiatives early was a positive step to help universities and students in their decision making processes and planning. The Petrie electorate includes the Carseldine campus of the Queensland University of Technology, a university that I have had an association with over a number of years, both as a student and as a tutor. I was very pleased to see that the Queensland University of Technology's operating grants for 1996‐97 have risen by 3.8 per cent and the variation for 1996‐98 is 4.9 per cent. I expect that the university will benefit from the research funding that has also been made available. The increased funding for university research is upwards of $140 million over four years.

The changes to the user‐pays system for university education will make it, I believe, a fairer system. The three‐tiered system will change for the better the irregularity that existed before. The new proposals are a far more equitable system, streamlining the process which existed where everyone was charged the same, regardless of which course they undertook. Australian students will also be given the opportunity to purchase an undergraduate place, in the same way that overseas students can do now. The reality is that education costs money. We live in a user‐pays society, and the variations to the HECS system will provide far more equity.

Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a chronic shortage of carers in our community. I have made the point of speaking to many community groups, such as St Catherine's Respite Centre—a St Vincent de Paul centre in the Petrie electorate. The centre caters for approximately 40 clients a day, providing a freshly cooked three‐course meal for lunch in a very caring and supportive environment. I have spoken to a number of church and community groups concerning this issue. Respite centres in the Petrie electorate, unfortunately, are limited.

There is certainly a great need for overnight centres and occasional weekend care. Those who spend their lives comforting and supporting others must be applauded for their wonderful efforts. If these dedicated people were not so committed, the situation would be far worse than it is today. I will do everything I can to support the needs of carers in my electorate. I will work towards this cause in providing overnight care and weekend occasional care. This is a quality of life issue, and everybody deserves a break to settle their own nerves and their own system. The lifelong love and dedication which carers provide need to be rewarded.

The national carers action plan introduced by this government is a step towards this quality of life. This plan recognises the role that carers play, and their importance in today's society. I understand that there will be a focus on matching services and assistance to the needs and circumstances of individual carers. I am proud to see that this government has not ignored these carers and that we have taken them under our wing and will recognise and support their efforts.

The importance of this budget will not only have benefits for this country fiscally, but will also provide substantial benefits to the confidence of the business community and families. This budget will lay a foundation for this country's future and provide a far brighter future for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow my colleague the member for Petrie, and I acknowledge her interest and the interest of the member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent) in the small business sector. I look forward to working with them on the inquiry into fair trading and I hope that we can bring in a report that the government will implement.

SPEECH.PARA: The first budget of the Howard government, presented by the Treasurer Peter Costello, shows once more a lack of imagination from the conservative side of Australia politics in public policy making. In a short space of time, the Treasurer has already shown that he is clearly a slave to economic orthodoxy. There has to be a better way to build a better country than is shown in this budget. The fixation with budget deficits and ultra low inflation rates belies the fact that we need economic growth in which to create jobs.

The Howard government has clearly failed to recognise that the role of government is not just to balance the books like a small suburban accounting firm; it is actually to create the climate for economic growth and to redress market failures. Obviously, there have been significant market failures in Australia over the past 50 years. We have failed to address the need to replace jobs lost with new jobs for ordinary Australians.

In my electorate of Rankin there is a well known suburb called Inala, a suburb in which I grew up. When I was growing up, there were a number of opportunities for people to work. These included the heavy engineering firm at Rocklea, Evans Deakin Engineering, General Motors Holden at Acacia Ridge, and the Huttons Meatworks. All have since closed due to competitive pressure or rationalisation.

What this government needs to do is to turn economic policy into an instrument for creating jobs for these people. The unemployment in this suburb and in other areas in my electorate is unacceptable. It is one of the reasons we are now in opposition. However, the unemployment minister Senator Vanstone has admitted that unemployment will stay at 8 per cent until the year 2000. This is simply not good enough. From their own words the government has let down the unemployed in my electorate and across the country.

Let us take a look at what they think the answer is. But let us first say what the answer is not. The answer is not to smash the job schemes that actually help people find jobs, nor to cut $1.8 billion over four years out of labour market programs. I challenge government members to visit places like the Inala South‐West Skillshare office in my electorate and to speak with the 730 people who benefited from the Skillshare program during the last financial year. What are these people, and the hundreds of other people in my electorate who found jobs through the Skillshare programs, to do?

The government's answer is to cut funding for programs like the new enterprise incentive scheme—NEIS—and the jobskill program. These schemes have been successful in my electorate in areas such as Inala, Browns Plains and Woodridge. The answer is not to make the unemployed feel ashamed of their position and guilty by introducing things like the so‐called `dole diary'.

BREAK.PARA: As I talk to community groups in my electorate, I find one thing is certain. Senior citizens are concerned about and just plain scared of the consequences of this budget. The government's decision to align the nursing home system with the hostel system results in senior citizens having to pay an entry contribution to gain admittance to a nursing home. Older members of the community who need nursing homes may have to pay up‐front fees of around $26,000. We cannot yet get the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) to identify what the figure will be. She answers every other question, but will not answer this one.

The Minister of Family Services has tried to defend the decision by saying that it is simply a matter of aligning the two systems of nursing and hostel care. This is a ridiculous argument, and it is clear that she does not understand her own policy. You do not need to go through a test to get into a hostel as a matter of choice. You have to be assessed before you get into a nursing home and that is a fundamental difference. It is the reason that the previous government did not relate the two together. Anyone who has any understanding of aged care policy knows that the two types of care are indeed vastly different.

The increase in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will result in pensioners now paying an additional 50c per prescription, or $3.20 in total. Many of the pensioners I represent are angry that there was no warning of this sudden increase. There is not the compensation that there initially was when the scheme was introduced.

Many of my constituents who are on fixed incomes will find it difficult to deal with this sudden increase. For a sick pensioner it can mean up to an additional $5 per week. Elderly people who live at home and who have chosen to stay at home in familiar surroundings will be slugged user‐pays fees at a rate of around $4 per hour. The government has also reduced its contribution to home and community care funding by $88 million over four years.

All these measures make it difficult for pensioners, and they are right to ask why this government is hitting them so hard. Too often we have become slaves, however, to economic theory. That applies to all sections of the Australian political spectrum. What we have to do is find Australian solutions for Australian problems.

I recently listened to a debate on the ABC about what used to be called the `fair go country'. In fact, we have lost in recent years the attitude of a fair go for all. I think the election of this government is a further step away from it. Unless this government recommits itself to the philosophy of a fair go, we will end up as a society with a distinct underclass. I know this because I have seen many of the people in my electorate suffer under the types of programs that have been cut in this budget. What the budget will mean for low income families, pensioners and the unemployed is not a pretty picture.

Many members have spoken of how the scrapping of funding for the Commonwealth dental scheme will affect the community. I did some research and found out how many people in my electorate used this scheme, and I was simply staggered by the result. My electorate of Rankin had one of the highest usages of the scheme in Queensland. Over 13,000 residents in my electorate used the scheme during the last financial year. Over 7,000 residents and health care card holders in Logan City in my electorate used the scheme last year. So these people can now expect long queues and much pain from John Howard's broken promises.

Before this scheme was introduced, the cost of dental health care was out of the question for many poorer Australians. Under Labor, they were able to receive dental health care. This, cruelly, will no longer be the case. This is an absolute disgrace, and I will be making it clear to the people of Rankin that they have been forgotten by this government.

The only way for people to break out of the poverty cycle is through economic development and through jobs. Both of these objectives have not been met by this government in its first budget. Small and medium sized enterprises can offer many opportunities for Australians, as many speakers on the other side have said in their contributions to this debate.

Going back a little in time, the McKinsey report entitled Born global, which was brought down in 1993—I recommend it to all honourable members—showed how many Australian companies are able to focus on new markets, and the global market is part of their initial business plan. This is something that has not been part of Australian culture in the past and something the government needs to nurture.

It is not natural for Australian companies to think of international trade as their basic market. In the past, we have always been a country that fed its domestic market and sold any excess to export markets. We did not see exports as a primary source of income for business. But, when we see in this budget the EMDG scheme, the DIFF program and a whole range of other support programs attacked as business welfare, we see that the economic rationalists within the Treasury are getting their way with a continuing stream of coalition ministers.

These types of programs are not business welfare. They are addressing a market failure in creating an export culture. Because of our OECD membership, we also tend to think that we are a fully developed country. The opposite is true. We are still a developing country, admittedly with a very high standard of living but one that continues to improve. If we do not improve our standard of living, then many people within our society will fall through the net.

We have to look forward now and have a look at the safety net itself, to see how it is administered. We have to do so, not because it has failed or because we want to cut funding, but because we want to redirect it to enable Australians to become more part of a productive society. Unless we offer all Australians the right to work we will fail the test set down by this nation.

There are ways to create jobs and to do it through our natural resources. Australia is the world's leading mining nation. It is the leader in mining technology and mineral exploration.
