We are at the forefront of mining technology development. This is, of course, one of our most important sectors. We fail to realise that already we export more goods and services from the mining sector than from the well‐publicised wine industry.

Quite often, we do not recognise that research and development is taking place in these areas and that Australia is producing world‐class goods for export markets. What we need to do is promote them more and ensure that our trade bodies, such as Austrade and Ausmine, are given the support they need. Australia can set the trend. Most people would not realise that the first CD‐ROM technology exported by Australia was an adaptation of mining programs on teaching an operator how to use underground equipment. This was, as I said, done on CD‐ROM for the first time and exported out of Australia.

There are ways, of course, to create new employment. But we need to be forthright and not listen to the economic theorists who tell us what we cannot do rather than what we can do. In December 1995, during discussions I had with a major Japanese paper company, I asked the simple but obvious question of why this particular company had invested in paper production facilities in Canada and other countries but never in Australia. The answer was something of a revelation. It simply was that Australia had never told that particular company that they had to invest in Australia, whereas the Canadians had.

Many ministers have been told you cannot instruct overseas business to construct plant in Australia. The reality is that if you own the natural resource and you want to put a condition down you will get the investment. The Canadians have shown us how to do that. It is now time, I think, that Australia grasped the nettle.That is how we can overcome our trade deficit as well as create new jobs for all Australians. Unfortunately, this budget will not create jobs and will, in fact, add pain to those in the community who are unemployed. What we need is innovation and what we need is new ideas. What we have got in this budget is not just economic rationalism but economic orthodoxy. We have closed CES and DSS offices. With the cutbacks in job programs, with pensioners being hit, with the unemployed being offered no future and with cuts to child care, we can truly say that this government is certainly not governing for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent, Russell, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of a budget that restores Australian families and small businesses in our regions to their pre‐eminent position after 13 years of neglect from the former Hawke and Keating governments. In fact, having heard from the speakers today and having two of the guilty party, the member for Fowler (Mr Grace) and the member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), sitting here in this room, it is a pleasure for me to address this hallowed chamber and discuss a couple of matters that came out of the member for Rankin's address.

SPEECH.PARA: Talk about nowhere to run and nowhere to hide! These two are two of the guilty party. As the member for Rankin said, he watched his people suffer through 13 years of neglect in the seat of Rankin. Why did he not do something about it? As the former minister for small business, for heaven's sake, he was the minister who presided over small businesses in Australia paying 22 per cent interest rates. That was a total failure, not just on his behalf.

I noted, as he spoke today, that he still had some good ideas. He was one of the ministers who actually had some good ideas. But his own party walked away from him every time he put those ideas forward, because he actually used some commonsense. He actually went to the Japanese and talked to them about how he could get investment in Australia. But he was rejected, along with all those backbenchers and ministers who sat in regional seats. They were ignored by the executive. That is not happening with this government.

You saw—and I do not want to be distracted, Mr Deputy Speaker—that historic meeting where the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) brought together all of those people on the woodchip issue. He brought the conservationists together, he brought the industry people together and he brought the interested members of parliament together on the coalition side. They sat down and, very quickly, came up with an idea that is acceptable to the Australian community and provides a great opportunity for jobs in regional Australia.

The speech we have just heard from the member for Rankin shocked me. It shocked me in that, once again, they are using scaremongering with the elderly and the most vulnerable in our community. That is a great disappointment to me as the member for McMillan, having suffered through so much of this in my first three years here, watching a government use the scaremongering with the elderly and the vulnerable in our community through the whole of the Fightback package. And now I am seeing them doing exactly the same thing again in opposition.

No‐one pretends that this was an easy budget to deliver. In fact there must have been this huge sigh of relief in Labor ranks when they lost because they had nowhere to run, nowhere to hide. You heard the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) talk about job programs and denigrate the Prime Minister—as only the Labor Party do—by using language for the member for Bennelong. But I noticed you pulled him up, Mr Deputy Speaker—and I thank you for that—when he called him `Jobless Johnny'. At the same time the member for Perth said, `On the other hand—' and what was on the other hand? Nothing. He had no new ideas, no new policies and no hope.

What this budget brings to Australia is hope, and it returns to the people the ideas and the aspirations that they have for this nation. I repeat, no‐one has pretended it has been an easy budget to deliver. But most of the members on the other side of the House know that, had they been re‐elected, they would have been delivering a very similar budget. The decisions and the commitments made were difficult. At the same time, however, one cannot dispute that in this budget the burden of the challenges facing the Australian community has been delivered equitably. The government had no other course, after 13 years of mismanagement of the Australian economy, but to take the action that they have taken and spread the difficulties equally amongst the people.

This budget—in my humble opinion—is a tribute to the Prime Minister, John Howard, and to the Treasurer, Peter Costello, for the way they went about the process of fairness and equity to get an outcome like this that is not merely concerned with the next financial year, nor that reflects some pre‐occupation with reducing the deficit bequeathed by Labor. This budget is the first step towards retrieving a credible role for government in our community. In the face of growing cynicism and doubt, not only about the function of government but also about the very effectiveness of government itself, this budget establishes the foundations essential to resisting this trend by restoring credibility and honesty with respect to national governments.

In recent years we have witnessed the increasing perversion of due process in government. After so many years of incumbency, the former Labor government deluded itself by believing that it could retain power merely by being seen to do something. It overlooked the necessity to actually deliver real outcomes. In my electorate of McMillan prior to the election campaign we had the then local member, Mr Cunningham, announcing in the local paper that he had received $10 million in funding for the electorate. Little has been delivered. We cannot find it in any budget anywhere. Was it just another hollow promise? It is disappointing a whole lot of people around Moe.

I noticed that the Opposition Leader (Mr Beazley) actually mentioned funds withdrawn from Moe in Gippsland. There have been no funds withdrawn by this government. In fact, we have delivered exactly what we said we would. We said that, if this was a government commitment that had been signed off, we would do it—and we have done it. We have done it in every regional area.

The former government was an administration by style not substance. The dying days of the Keating government can best be described as a shell adorned by labels, such as Working Nation, Creative Nation, Young Nation, One Nation, with little to excuse its failures for 13 years. Labor had even less to justify its sixth term in office. In no other area of public policy was this more manifest than in the proliferation of labour market programs that paid absolutely no regard whatsoever to the effectiveness and performance of such schemes.

The former government's own adviser, DEETYA, in its report entitled Working Nation: evaluation of the employment, education and training elements determined after having carried out an assessment of labour market programs that Working Nation had failed by promoting placements in relatively expensive programs that failed to meet the measure of the quality expected. This report compounded the weight of growing evidence, which the government was electing to ignore, that effectively suggested that government concentrate on delivering real jobs rather than formulating programs. Other reports were compiled with the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the National Board of Employment, Education and Training.

The DEETYA report condemned Working Nation for shifting the number of placements away from such effective schemes as the jobclub program to programs such as new work opportunities. Under the new work opportunities program, the employer had no obligation to retain the employee, whereas under wage subsidy programs an incentive was available to encourage the retention of placements. In addition, taking on a trainee was far less expensive under NWO schemes than through many other labour market programs.

While the number of placements in wage subsidy programs was intended to increase, there was an evident decline in the number of these positions. For example, in 1993, 26 per cent of program placements were in the jobstart program. That figure fell to 18 per cent in 1994‐95 and to 17 per cent in the first eight months of 1995‐96. There is ample evidence to suggest that the new work opportunities program was competing for placements in the private sector together with other DEETYA programs.

The basis of the more expensive labour market programs was not solely flawed on account of effectiveness. Those programs were placed in areas without, it would appear, any genuine consideration of the priority attaching to such assistance. Administrative data reveals that 15 per cent of all new work opportunities program placements went to the 30 DEETYA areas with the lowest unemployment levels while only 16 per cent of all new work opportunities placements were landed in the 30 DEETYA areas with the highest levels of unemployment.

Sufficient time does not exist here to fully trace the failings of Working Nation. What can be said is that Labor has attempted to disguise a policy vacuum with a myriad of programs, distorted incentives and avoided any transparent commitment to real outcomes. In contrast, the transitional and long term initiatives contained in this budget are premised not on programs but on outcomes. They are focused on the individual and not on remote or misbegotten targets.

This budget will establish the framework within which the range of labour exchange services can actually be expanded. At the same time those programs that have demonstrated effectiveness will be retained such as new enterprise incentive schemes, NEIS, and various English and literacy programs.

Regions, like my electorate of McMillan, will benefit by the retention of the Office of Labour Market Adjustment; regional community employment councils, formerly area consultative committees; and the forest industry adjustment package. I note also with very great pleasure the allocation of $48 million towards the finalisation of regional forest agreements. I know that the timber industry, which supports many families in my electorate, will benefit directly from this initiative.

It is appropriate at this time to congratulate the government on its decision to lift the woodchip export ceiling by one million tonnes. The decision is much more than the export ceiling; the decision represents country jobs for country people in the electorate of McMillan. Over 1,000 jobs directly depend on this industry in my electorate. Countless other jobs rest upon the activity and employment in the timber industry. I know that employees, management, the NFF, the VFF, the Forest Protection Society and the CFMEU have worked diligently to correct many of the myths surrounding the industry in Australia. Were it not for their confidence in the Howard government, this process would have been rendered far more difficult.

It also provides medium to long‐term supply security which is so vital to the industry. Many industry representatives in McMillan have long been restricted in their investment decisions by uncertainty as well as the risk of government policy decisions over the years. We have witnessed so many of these. By accelerating the conclusion of RFAs, this budget allows for a stable and sound environment for investment planning. The process that has been outlined by the Prime Minister encourages managers to adopt thinning operations which maximise future sawlog yields in production forests and illustrates the government's commitment to the national forest policy statement as well as value adding in Australia by providing an incentive for woodchip exporters to source their material from sawmills.

The modern Australian apprenticeship training scheme guarantees much‐needed flexibility that has been absent. We have been neglecting the needs of our young unemployed, not to mention their prospective employers. The wage top‐up serves as a safeguard for apprentices, trainees and employers. I have noted with annoyance that the opposition has levelled criticism at the principle of apprentices being paid only for productive time in work. This is a principle which has been accepted by both parties. For the Labor Party to oppose in opposition what it embraced in government is manifestly opportunistic.

I turn now to the issue of health. Before I do, I will just make my point on how important the woodchip situation is. I will not say who sent me the fax; I will just read out what that fax says. They are talking about an address I made in the House yesterday. It says:

I caught up with your spirited defence of the new woodchip regulations. I understand the shadow resources minister, Neil O'Keefe, made his usual destructive contribution on this matter. I appreciate your support for our industry as the past environment has created much uncertainty and has caused much unnecessary hardship in rural Australia. Thanks again. Look forward to catching up with you soon.
That is just another person seriously concerned about jobs in regional Australia.

I know the member at the table agrees with every word I am saying on this. I come from a position where I cannot believe that you can sit here and be as brazen as you were today in the House during question time when you know that, between 1990 and 1993, you sat there while employment increased 150 per cent. It went from 3,000 to 9,000 in the seat that I formerly held. It is an indictment of you that you can actually sit there and think that we are not going to do the best that we possibly can for those people who are unemployed. We will do it. Everything this government can afford we will do on behalf of those people who are unemployed and genuinely looking for jobs.

The health portfolio, better than most, demonstrates Labor's impotence in office. Despite having virtually unlimited resources to effect change, Labor was constrained not only by its industrial wing—to no‐one's surprise—but also by a commitment to a version of universality that guaranteed neither access to public health services nor fairness.I suspect Labor considered that, by its commitment to a standard Medicare levy in the absence of private health insurance rebates, it was addressing the current crisis in our public health system. Sadly, its commitment in this regard became a pretext for inaction.

Only the coalition has had the courage and the sense of social justice to embrace a two‐tiered Medicare system, requiring the wealthy in our community to contribute more to the operation of our public health system. I am sure I would be supported by every member in this room on that issue. The Medicare surcharge for high income earners is an eminently fair measure, adding perspective to our health system. The long‐term maintenance of the public sector depends on greater contributions from higher income earners. The availability of rebates places singles, couples and families in a better position than they enjoyed under Labor.

While the availability of rebates for private health cover has been affected by recent increases in health fund premiums, let us remember that the recent increases and impending applications for increases are a direct result of the trend of decline in the number of people taking out private cover. For the opposition to attack the coalition on this front is unforgivable. It is worthy of dismissal for what it really is: a desperate attempt to repair its poor performance in the polls and its poor performance on the health issue.

In the establishment of the inquiry by the Productivity Commission into the state of health funds, the government has acted promptly to ensure that the value of these premiums is maintained. In fact, access to health services will be further enhanced in electorates like McMillan. Allowing pharmacies to serve as Medicare agencies will improve access for clients and pensioners in Australia's regions and more remote areas.

I am incensed when I hear criticism from the opposition in the wake of our announcement of our intention to reform the aged care sector. It is the height of hypocrisy for a party which introduced an identical system for hostels to now oppose the implementation of the very same system in nursing homes. Unifying the hostel and nursing home system is a measure necessary to address a steadily worsening crisis in nursing home care. In simple terms, nursing homes around the country have not been able to attract sufficient funds to upgrade facilities. Many premises are increasingly dilapidated and fail to meet the standards that we, as a community, should expect for the elderly.

In 1994, the then Labor government commissioned a report on the state of nursing homes. After surveying 150 nursing homes, the following findings—amongst others—were made: 75 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Australian design standards; 13 per cent of homes failed to meet fire authority standards; and 39 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more beds.

The government's objective for aged care is twofold. Firstly, the package allows sufficient funds to address the capital crisis facing many homes; and, secondly, it removes inequities between the nursing home and hostel systems in order that the financially disadvantaged will be protected, while those who can afford to make a contribution will be able do so. Twenty per cent of people who are financially disadvantaged will not be paying to go into a nursing home. They will not be charged $26,000. And everybody on the opposition side knows exactly that. Importantly, full‐time pensioners are exempt from having to make any entry contributions. So, too, are financially disadvantaged persons who have not owned a home in the last two years.

What people need to understand is that entry contributions, which are established by agreement between management and client, will not be compulsory. While the contribution is to be negotiated between the prospective resident and the proprietor, there are very strict conditions under which arrangements can be finalised. Very secure safeguards exist for the benefit of prospective residents.

We should remember that, under the previous government, millionaires enjoyed better access to nursing home beds than the battlers who so conclusively deserted Labor at the last election campaign. For instance, a resident must always be left with assets of at least 250 per cent of the pension—some $22,000—and the entry contribution can only be drawn down at the maximum rate of $2,600 per year for a limit of five years. Members on the other side know that.

Most significantly, people will not be forced to sell their own homes at fire sale prices. The same system implemented by Labor for hostels in 1988 will now be applied to nursing homes. While people are given six months to sell their homes, if they fail to do so they cannot be ejected from their accommodation. Their draw‐down simply becomes a debt due to the proprietor. A further guarantee exists in that no prospective resident will be asked to make any contribution within the first six months of admission to a nursing home.

I do not have the opportunity today to address other issues which are so important and specific in this budget. My community is relieved that the years of the Keating and Hawke governments have gone. We now have the opportunity to build on this budget to make sure that we deliver the promises and the programs that are in it on behalf of the Australian people. I see myself as having had a great blessing in being able to make this address on behalf of the constituents of McMillan. I will serve everyone of them, whichever way they have voted, to the best of my ability. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams, Dick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent) talked about coming from a regional area. McMillan certainly is a region of Victoria. Regional areas were certainly betrayed in this budget—totally betrayed. They were betrayed and abandoned, and the honourable member for McMillan's electorate was abandoned. The Department of Regional Affairs has been gutted—there is no longer a department. The minister has said that there is no clear rational or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development. The minister's statement has wiped out the Department of Regional Affairs. But it is easy to compare what this budget takes away from regional Australia with what Labor had in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The federal member for Wannon, David Hawker, who is chairman of the Federal Liberal Regional and Rural Committee, said in a press release on 21 July 1995:

It is a disgrace that people who choose to work and live in the country often have to put up with the inadequate or non‐existent services. While many of the capital cities have started to recover from the hard‐hitting recession, that recovery has not flowed on to regional areas.

I would like to say to David, and to the member for McMillan and all the other members representing regional Australia in this government: `Let's talk about some of those services.' Let's talk about the Medicare offices which have been closed right around Australia. This budget closed them in regional Australia. And it is no good putting in your rebate claim at the chemist—the chemist does not have a fax machine that can refund you with dollars and cents.

Social Security and CES offices have been closed in regional Australia. They are regional services that apply within Australia. They are regional offices right around the country and they are being closed. The tax offices are being closed in Launceston. People in that area have to go all the way to Hobart to talk to somebody in the tax office. That makes things really difficult for older people who like to talk to a tax official on a one‐to‐one basis. They cannot do it anymore. Bingo! Out it goes. With this budget, this government, out it goes.

The Family Court in Launceston is being downgraded. I do not know whether there are other family courts in other parts of regional Australia. If there are, I am sure they are under attack and I am sure they are under pressure of closure. This all happens in regional Australia. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent) is listening very intently, and so he should, because his region has been betrayed by this budget.

University places have been lost in regional universities. In Tasmania, we have lost 380 places from our university. We were very fortunate and we worked very hard—and I know you did too, Mr Deputy Speaker—to increase the opportunities in the northern part of Tasmania and also in the north‐west so that, especially in the north‐west which has one of the lowest retention rates of tertiary education in Australia, we would have more places for people up there. We have lost that opportunity and those places are now under pressure.

Thirty places have been lost at the Australian Maritime College in Launceston. That is a loss to the north of Tasmania. A report I was looking at recently on the economics of northern Tasmania stated that 23 per cent of its economic activity comes from education—university, the Maritime College, secondary colleges and other educational facilities. So that is a big loss to the state and to that part of Tasmania.

Labor's $150 million in infrastructure funding has gone out of the budget. Bingo! It is taken out of the budget; there is no more infrastructure. There was no rational or constitutional basis for that decision, but the minister does not believe that this government has a constitutional or a rational reason for being in anything to do with regional development.

The sale of Telstra will affect regional Australia enormously. Tasmania will lose at least 600 jobs for a start, and that is a big loss of incomes for Tasmania. There has been some discussion that digital mobile telephones will be the answer for regional Australia and that regional Australia does not need to have the same services as urban areas. I think this is what is being pushed to all the regional members of the government. They are telling them that mobile phones are the answer for regional Australia.

At the moment, 70 per cent of the base stations are located in metropolitan areas, 25 per cent are located in regional areas and five per cent are located in remote areas. I sourced that from answers to a question on notice from the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) on 20 August 1996. So only a small proportion of regional Australia currently has access to mobile phones.

There will not be an increase in the infrastructure in the less populated areas after privatisation. Even if there was, the mobile phone does not allow the same interactive communication that is available on the Internet or e‐mail. It does not allow CD‐ROM. It cannot give access to the information systems of the world in the same way that is possible with a physical cable. Without Telstra's current ability to cross‐subsidise services, the regional areas will be forgotten and discounted and they will not receive the roll‐out of the cable.

Tasmania is in a very vulnerable position. I worry greatly about its being able to receive that roll‐out. If they do not have this technology, will the individuals, organisations and areas be at an economic disadvantage? It would certainly heighten Tasmania's isolation, as it would with many other regions throughout Australia.
Then there is the $600 million sliced off national highway funding. They have pork‐barrelled a bit up in the northern part of New South Wales and given the members up there some areas—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, they have taken $600 million off the national highway funding. I think this translates to about $9 million less for Tasmania's highways. Last week the Brew report indicated that they are trying to get rid of our railways. It is a double whammy, of course: they are taking money off the highway system in this budget and closing the national railways in Tasmania, or trying to. There will certainly be a significant loss of work on the Bass Highway and I am sure there are places in the Penguin area and other areas towards the north‐west coast where work was being phased in that will probably also be set back.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the loss of the last government's labour market programs, comparing this budget with what was there under a Labor government. These programs were about skill development for long‐term unemployed and for young people. It was the opportunity to gain skills through some of these programs. Skillshare is about giving skills to some people who would not get into TAFE, people who would need help with basic literacy and numeracy, basic English, that sort of training, in order to have skills to find a job, to have an opportunity to compete, to have a chance of competing on equal terms with others in that very competitive job market. Those people are going to be denied an opportunity with a 33 per cent cut in the skillshare budget. So there is going to be a reduction in labour market programs, a reduction in chances for people to gain skills, a reduction in opportunities for them to be able to get job ready and a reduction in training for some of those young people who need to come through a program before they can go towards an employer to be taken on board as an employee.

You can say that these were Mickey Mouse programs, you can say whatever you wish about them and run them down—which the other side does—but they were programs that were there to assist long‐term unemployed and other unemployed. And when we, first as a government and then as an opposition, have sought to find out what this current government would set itself as a target to reduce unemployment, it has refused to tell. So this government has been able to cut $1.8 billion out of labour market programs and it has cut that at the expense of the unemployed, young people, long‐term unemployed, people who did have some hope, who had some opportunity to gain skills that would make them somewhat competitive in a very competitive labour market. By cutting that, by getting rid of that, we have reduced the opportunity for a lot of those people. They are to have a test on whether the opportunity to do a course is worth while, and it will be very interesting to see how many people are thrown on the scrap heap using that sort of technique.

Then there is the ABC. The Launceston office of the ABC and the local programs are under enormous threat, especially in future years. Over the next four years the ABC will lose $209 million—$11 million next year and then $66 million each year for the next three years. Regional Australia has got to take a loss when you start cutting the ABC like that. We are going to have the networking of programs out of Melbourne and Sydney and we are going to lose regional programming right round the country. It will devastate the ABC and will mean the loss in Tasmania, I am sure, of the symphony orchestra. Local programs will disappear and all our news and current affairs will probably come out of Sydney.

What relevance does all this have to regional Australia? Those members opposite who represent regional Australia have failed to be able to contribute to the debate within this government. They have failed to take up the issues that are really relevant to regional Australia.

BREAK.PARA: There are the losses and changes also to programs, such as the reducing of the tax concession from 150 per cent for research and development to 125 per cent. This puts at risk programs that were being started in our country. For instance, it has recently become technically feasible to treat primary sulphide concentrates by bacterial oxidation to dissolve copper, followed by solvent extraction and electrowinning of the copper. Simply, this is using technology to mine and retrieve the copper concentrate.

The new Mount Lyell mine, at Queenstown, is experimenting with producing copper on site rather than sending it overseas to be smelted. This is a new way of smelting, a new technology. This is about smartness. This is about doing things better and differently. This is a good, value adding project, something that we desperately need in my state of Tasmania and in the rest of regional Australia. The project would have three stages over three years in conjunction with BacTech, one of two or three companies in the world who have the technology to treat these copper concentrates in this manner.

So here we are, getting on the edge of technology and being knocked over by a really silly, stupid decision of a government trying to play at a political level about something to do with big black holes. This would have meant 30 to 40 jobs and the long‐term the viability of this mine, which has to make itself a viable proposition over the next few years. The project is at risk. Why? Because this government really is not looking at the future. It did not have any vision in this budget. When I have heard members from the other side speak in the budget debate on the appropriations bill here, all they have wanted to do is to attack this side of the House. They want to attack the previous government but lack putting much vision into the future. They have failed to be able to go in there and take on the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the executive of this government, and to be able in any way to influence this.

All those members who have come in from regional Australia have been walked over, and regional Australia has been the loser. The betrayal of the private sector, which is taking risks for the future, is a really silly decision. The government has a vital role to play in facilitating this and should have been in there doing it.

Then there is the loss of the $150 million in infrastructure funding, putting other projects at risk. Orielton Lagoon, in southern Tasmania, is at risk. There is an irrigation scheme here and an effluent recycling project. The feasibility study showed the export opportunities for farmers involved in new crops in this area.

In my electorate, just over from the airport of southern Tasmania, there are close opportunities for cherry farming, for intensive farming, taking water out of a recycling sewage farm and putting that water on to the golf club, selling the water to the golf club, selling it to farmers. The feasibility study has been done, all the engineering is done and all we needed was a bit of capital to make it happen. Of course, bingo: $150 million infrastructure funds for regional Australia, bingo. `No constitutional responsibility,' says the minister.

I turn to the shipbuilding bounty. Everybody knows the Incat success story in Tasmania. Some of the rewards that we have there are at risk. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Senator Vanstone) talks about real jobs. Real jobs have been created there, with new jobs in welding and aluminium product, and very new skills have been founded. A lot of work has gone into building up the skill base.

The bounty was reviewed in February 1995 and the report found that the industry had totally transformed itself in the 1980s from a domestic situation to export, and about 80 per cent of the production is now exported. Why change a success story? It is very hard to understand and it is just a stupid decision by government to do so.

Then there is the hydrodynamic facility at the maritime college in northern Tasmania. This would have been a world class third‐generation ocean testing basin. It would have put Australia at the forefront of this type of research. The sort of research that they are doing there in the maritime college is work on the platforms for the oil rigs that are now being made in Australia at Bunbury, I think, in Western Australia and at Newcastle on the east coast. The technology for these things has been developed in the test tanks at the maritime college in Launceston. Fourteen million dollars would have given us a facility that would have put us at the leading edge of technology, but that has been knocked back by this government, using this budget. So the honourable member representing that region has failed that region miserably.

I could go on. I have not touched on things like funding to the state governments for programs such as housing, dental care, child care, superannuation, elderly care—all these programs that really matter to families. Government members have been quite forceful in saying that they represent families. Families are the basis of all those programs that are affected by the cuts in this budget. The families will feel the disappointment, the let‐down, of the many broken promises.

The government has been very short‐sighted in this budget. It has failed to give a vision, a hope, to many different groups within the community that were probably thinking that with a new government there would be new opportunities and we would get some vision. But the government wanted to play around with the politics of the edge. They talked about a $9 billion deficit, black holes, et cetera. But they offered no vision to our industries or opportunities to help the long‐term unemployed by putting in place the programs that needed to be put in place.

This government is wishy‐washy. It does not have a clue about how to stimulate job creation in this economy. It has failed. Its ministers are in disarray in the other place. The minister in our House is talking about trying to get the number of apprentices up, but he does not even know in which industries he is going to get the apprentices up.

Australia has been betrayed. Regional Australia has been abandoned, betrayed, forgotten and run away from by all those members on the other side who came in from regional Australia. It is a shame, and they should be ashamed that they have let down their electorates. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brough, Mal, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in the short time available to me tonight I would like to make a few points relating to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams). First of all, let me say that 77 per cent of the Australian population have already spoken. They have told us that they believe this is a fair, equitable and responsible budget, which is something that has not been achieved in my memory and certainly not in the last 13 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make a couple of quick comments regarding his last remarks. I noted down on the pad in front of me the words `short‐sighted approach'. I think that is exactly what the Labor Party had. The fact that they were willing to sell the future by overspending now indicated quite rightly that they had no long‐term vision. In fact, they were quite prepared to sell off the farm. They were quite prepared to go further into debt in order to fulfil their short‐term goals rather than to look at the long term.

They talk about the failure of the minister for employment. That is hypocrisy at its best. Six months we have been here. The Telstra bill, the industrial relations bill and the budget—the things with which we went to the people—are not yet through the parliament. When the legislation is passed and they have had time to be put into place and to have an effect, we will see real jobs created. I think that we are going to pay the price for taking an honest approach to government.

We saw in the lead‐up to the last election so many people being put into jobs. I should say `into outcomes'. They are not jobs; they are long‐term training projects. They enable people to come off the long‐term unemployment list and on to the short‐term unemployment list. They do not create a job; they do not create any wealth for Australia; they do not give these people any hope. They simply made the government of the day look better. I will perhaps leave to my second instalment my other comments regarding the budget, which the greater percentage of Australians acknowledge was the correct measure to take.

I make reference to A fair go for families, a publication put out by the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission. This is to pre‐empt the debate that will take place in the main chamber perhaps tomorrow in relation to the family tax laws. It states:
A simple method of moving towards a fairer taxation system for families would be to introduce additional tax thresholds in respect of dependents.
That is exactly what this government has done. It goes on:
This would recognise the additional minimum costs incurred by families with dependents.

This publication of 1987 was available to the previous Labor government for some eight years, yet it never took it up. In our first term we have taken it up and on 1 January of this year we will see those tax cuts come into effect.

There are two issues I would like to address in the very short time available. The first one is aged care in my own electorate of Longman. Aged Care Queensland has put a submission together which will be going to the federal and state ministers for family services in the next few days. This submission identifies particular areas of Longman as being the most disadvantaged areas when it comes to nursing homes.

The area of Bribie Island in particular is one which has seen a great deal of growth, particularly for elderly people as they move there for the fishing, the beaches, the fine weather and, of course, the quiet lifestyle. It has also resulted in the fact that we have only 50 places in total, provided by one nursing home, for the entire population. The population of people aged 70 and over is some 3,000 to 4,000. This means that in reality, to be able to meet the criteria, we should have somewhere between 300 and 400 nursing home places and we have 50. The situation in Caboolture is no better.

In the past the whole approach to nursing home places has been totally misdirected. We have talked of regions, and Bribie Island and Caboolture come into a planning region called Cabool. Pine Rivers Shire is also part of that particular region. That helps to equalise the numbers. It means that through this process we have been unable to deliver the places where they are needed and where the elderly population wish to live.

We do not, unfortunately, have a large population. The Gold Coast, known as the south coast region, has 3,021 aged care places for a population of 30,939 over 70 years of age. This means that they are underserviced by only 73 places. In the area of Cabool, we are 224 places underserviced. If we were fully serviced just in the Bribie‐Caboolture area alone, all of those places would be taken.

BREAK.PARA: I am reassured by Aged Care Queensland that they are recommending 30 places be allocated to Caboolture and 70 to Bribie Island to bolster the already high quality establishments that are there, such as the Bribie Island Retirement Village and the War Veterans' Home at Caboolture, not to mention Sunnymead Nursing Home.

Finally, I would like to bring to the committee's attention the plight of the Autistic Association of Queensland. I have been meeting today with two people, Mr Bruce Faye, the President of the Autism Association of Queensland, and Carol Renard.

Of all the areas of special needs, this particular group is probably the most disadvantaged because, as these people pointed out to the minister and myself today, if you have in this room people suffering from perhaps Down Syndrome, it is quite obvious. Their impediments can be seen and it is very obvious visually. People with autism look just like you and me. The fact is that the needs they have are very much specialised. They need additional care. Unfortunately, in Queensland at this stage we have an absolute lack of people available to service the parents, the school teachers and the carers, as well as the children who suffer from autism.

Whilst people with autism look 100 per cent healthy, their behavioural patterns and ability to communicate are often extremely lacking. The additional care they require is imperative if the families are going to have any quality of life and if the teachers are able to assist them, in particular in regional Queensland where we have one staff member looking after more than 400 families with autistic children. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 29 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many items of rolling stock are (a) owned or (b) leased by National Rail.
(2) How many items referred to in part (1), in each category, are not in use.
(3) Where are the items not in use being stored.
(4) What will National Rail do with the items not in use.
(5) What is the value of the items in storage (a) as scrap and (b) on the market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) NR currently owns 121 wagons (with others in production) and leases 4,949 wagons.

(2) 56 of the wagons owned by NR (plus 100 which are unserviceable) are not currently in use. All of the leased wagons are in use. NR has returned, or is in the process of returning, some 626 wagons to the NSW State Rail Authority, the Public Transport Commission of Victoria and Australian National, while 300 have been returned to Westrail.
(3) Stirling North, Adelaide, Angaston, Tailem Bend and Junee.
(4) Wagons not in use are available for use for commercial traffic or parts recovery.
(5) The scrap value of the stored, unserviceable wagons is $110,000. They are largely obsolete and have no market value other than scrap.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 29 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many items of rolling stock are (a) owned or (b) leased by Australian National.
(2) How many items referred to in part (1), in each category, are (a) on lease to National Rail and (b) available for Australian National's own use.
(3) How many items referred to in part (2) are not in use.
(4) How many of the items referred to in part (3) are (a) to be scrapped and (b) in storage.
(5) What is the value of the items in storage (a) as scrap and (b) on the market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian National (AN) has advised that it currently has 5,609 items of rolling stock, either owned or leased. These comprise 4,618 freight wagons, 160 passenger cars, seven railcars and 824 non‐commercial wagons.

(2) 2,040 freight wagons are on lease to National Rail (NR) as at 15 June 1996. The rest, including non‐commercial wagons (eg brake vans, wagons used for track maintenance) are available for AN's own use.
(3) 1,488 freight wagons, mostly broad gauge, are not in use by AN.
(4) AN has not determined which wagons are to be scrapped. None is in storage.
(5) AN has not assessed the scrap or market value of wagons not in use. As most of the wagons are obsolete, they would have little value apart from scrap.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Over what routes, including those operated jointly with other railways, did Australian National provide passenger services when it was established in 1975.
(2) How many services were provided on each route per week.
(3) Over what routes, including those operated jointly with other railways, does Australian National provide passenger services.
(4) How many services are provided on each route per week.

(5) On what date did Australian National (a) add new services or (b) increase the frequency of existing services between 1 July 1975 and the date of answering this question and in each case what route was involved.

(6) On what dates did Australian National (a) abolish or (b) decrease the frequency of existing services between 1 July 1975 and the date of answering this question and in each case what route was involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) AN was legally established in 1975 but did not assume operational responsibility for the amalgamated system until 1978. Information is not available for 1975, but in March 1978, AN provided passenger services on the following routes at the following frequencies:
Port Pirie‐Kalgoorlie—seven return services per week (four Indian Pacific services and three Trans‐Australian services)

For example, the SA State Government closed fourteen rural passenger services in 1968 and 1969.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps are being taken to ensure that all computer systems in the Minister's Department or any agency or statutory authority for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility are modified so that they continue to operate properly after 1 January 2000.
(2) What is the estimated cost of the modifications.
(3) Will all systems be modified by 1 January 2000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department has for some time been examining potential exposures to the Year 2000 issue. It is working with the Office of Government Information Technology Year 2000 Subcommittee and has developed a project plan to ensure that all such exposures are resolved.

(2) Many of the costs are being absorbed into normal processes which include scrapping obsolete systems and making changes as hardware is upgraded and as software is redeveloped. An estimate of the net additional cost is not available yet.
(3) The project plan provides for all systems continuing beyond 1 January 2000 to be Year 2000 compliant well before that date.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that almost all first release CDs contain as little as 35 minutes of recorded material and cost approximately $30 each but CDs of rereleased music and classical music may contain up to 73 minutes of recorded material and are much less expensive.
(2) Are young purchasers of CDs who are the mainstay of first release music financially disadvantaged by the way CDs are marketed.
(3) Will he act to make it mandatory for the cover of all first release CDs to show the actual playing time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost of first release CDs is approximately $30. However, of the twenty top selling CDs as at 26 August 1996, the average playing time was approximately 57 minutes. A number of first release CDs are being sold with an accompanying free CD or free video, resulting in a total playing time of almost 100 minutes and only two of the CDs in the top 20 at 26 August had a playing time of less than 40 minutes.
CDs of rereleased material may contain up to 73 minutes of recorded material and may be less expensive.

(2) If young purchasers are the mainstay of first release music, then it may be true that at times they are paying more than purchasers of rereleased or classical music. However, attributes such as originality or quality of the artist influence price, as well as duration. The fact that first release CDs are the dominant selling CDs suggests that they are being purchased for reasons other than duration of recording.
(3) I have no plans to make it mandatory for the cover of all first release CDs to show the actual playing time.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Do any railways in Australia or overseas have reflective strips or other devices on the side of locomotives or rolling stock to alert motorists of their presence on level crossings that do not have gates or flashing lights.
(2) Have any studies been done on the effectiveness of these measures; if so, what do these studies show.
(3) What would be the per unit indicative cost of placing such devices on locomotives and wagons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of rail systems in Australia and overseas have trialled reflective material on rolling stock or used it on a large scale. These include the Burlington Northern Railroad, Canadian Pacific and Canadian National in North America. The NSW State Rail Authority has over the last few years progressively fitted reflective logos to its grain hoppers. The Victorian Public Transport Corporation has fixed reflective material to about one third of its grain fleet and intends to complete the process. National Rail has also trialled reflective strips.

(2) A number of such tests have been done in Australia and overseas. A summary of recent studies is contained in Part 5 of the Proceedings of the 17th Conference (1994) of the Australian Road Research Board at pages 231 to 242. This study reports that there is a lack of definitive information on their effectiveness, but some railroads consider the devices to be useful. The Australian National Railways Commission (AN) considers that trials have not demonstrated that the measures tested led to an improvement in level crossing safety.
(3) AN has advised that the indicative cost of placing reflective material on a wagon varies from $30 to $70. The variation is due to the size and type of material and the way it is attached.
